PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Discrimination against Women

To the Honourable The President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respecfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
1. Undue cost to the nation at this time.

2. ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

3. The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
4. The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from three citizens), Robertson (from two citizens ) and Ryan (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Home Attendant Care Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That many services provided by the Commonwealth of Australia for disabled persons are not accessible or appropriate to people with multiple sclerosis. This includes sheltered workshops and facilities designed for geriatric patients in private nursing homes.

That, being members of the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Victoria who have multiple sclerosis or other allied diseases we believe the accommodation, day care, domiciliary support and family support services being promoted by the M.S. S.V. are worthwhile, even vital, and need further government support.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Expedite the implementation of a home attendant care scheme which will also reduce inappropriate and costly admissions to the nursing home and public health sector.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That passage of the Sex Discrimination Bill re-affirms the commitment of the Government in ratifying the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against women through:
1. Recognition of the dignity of all humans through equal rights for men and women.

2. Supporting the rights of women to choose education, employment and lifestyles beyond the traditional stereotyped concepts of the roles of men and women. The legislation in no way denies the validity of any particular role including traditional parental roles.
3. Providing legislative protection against discrimination to women living in States which have no existing discrimination legislation.
4. By acknowledging the discriminatory nature of sexual harrassment an occupational health hazard which seriously affects many women in employment.

We the undersigned believe that passage of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983, will provide a legislative base to honour the principles of equality incorporated in the U N Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against women.
Your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senate will support the legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The concerns which people around the World have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is it a fact that the Industries Assistance Commission recommended on 26 April that action be taken to correct an anomalous situation whereby one of the world' s largest steel wire producers-Korea-was accorded preferential tariff treatment? Is it a fact that, because of the urgency of the situation and the number of jobs at stake, the previous Government had placed a 45-day time limit on the IAC 's inquiry and report? Is the Minister aware that, almost five months later, the Department of Trade is still preventing action being taken to correct the anomaly? Is the Minister concerned at the delay? What action can or will he take to resolve the situation?

—I am aware of the situation described by Senator Chaney. I cannot confirm the exact dates but I do not in any sense seek to avoid the implications of the question by referring to the dates. The question of the operation of the Australian system of tariff preference and the preferences to be accorded to countries known as 'developing countries' for the purpose of the preference system is a matter for determination by myself and the Minister for Trade. I can only say that I am very much aware of the urgency of the situation. I personally am disturbed by the delays. I had a discussion with the Minister for Trade about the matter last week. I hope to see him again today on the same matter with a view to its being resolved this week.

—I refer the Minister for Industry and Commerce to the announcement last week of the Government's decision to encourage the development of a substantial venture capital market in Australia. Is the Minister aware of criticism of the Government's proposal by the Sydney Morning Herald last Friday? Will the Minister explain how the Government's proposals will operate to stimulate investment in high technology industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sydney Morning Herald article, which had the flamboyant title 'Garbage in, garbage out', attracted my attention because it was not the normal heading which one finds in an editorial in such a distinguished newspaper as the Sydney Morning Herald.
—Unless they are writing about your policies.

—That is a very convenient interjection for me to make one or two points about the policy which the Government has adopted in relation to this matter. In terms of encouraging venture capital for the support and encouragement of high technology industries, Australia is probably about eight years behind the times-a coincidence which, if one studies who was in government at the time, I cannot avoid drawing to the attention of the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: After a number of years of persistent effort by the current Minister for Science and Technology, the Fraser Government in 1980-81 established a committee of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences to examine this question. That committee reported earlier this year. I must say that the committee's work, which has in essence been adopted by the Government, is a refreshing innovation in terms of the situation in Australian industry generally.
I wish to refer the Senate to what the Espie High Technology Financing Committee concluded on the basic issue which is now of concern and which was addressed in the Sydney Morning Herald.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who set it up?

—I just gave the Fraser Government credit for that. It set up that Committee. All I was complaining about was that it was set up seven years too late. That is a classic sort of lead time for Liberal Party governments in Australia.
—Why didn't Gough do it?

—If Opposition senators want to presist with interjections, I feel nothing but assisted by them. If they want to raise points which have already been dealt with in the answer, they can go ahead. The Espie Committee concluded:

ANSWER.PARA: This Committee knows of no country which has succeeded in establishing a climate for investment in high technology enterprises without the Government taking positive action and, at a minimum, adopting a catalytic role.

Those honourable senators who have studied the Espie report will note that in its concluding chapters it draws attention to the government assistance provided for the establishment of high technology industries and particularly the attraction of venture capital into these areas in about a dozen countries in all , all of which have had much better performances in these matters, with the possible exception of the Republic of Ireland, than has Australia. In relation to the Sydney Morning Herald article--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the IAC report, before you get to the Sydney Morning Herald?
—Order! I invite the Minister to respond to Senator Sibraa's question.

—I have no doubt that Senator Rae will have a question later, and he can ask it then. In response to Senator Sibraa's question, let me say that there seems to be a quite fundamental misunderstanding in the Sydney Morning Herald article because it suggests that, as a result of the adoption of the program by the Government and its announcement last week, some $43m will be available to high technology industries and the assumption in the editorial is that that will be done in terms of grants to specific industries. That is not correct. What will be provided under the proposals adopted by the Government is a capacity for the establishment of management investment companies which will provide two things in the high technology area. The first will be finance which will not be government finance but private sector finance. The second will be management expertise. They are the two things which have been identified by Espie and numerous other critics as most lacking in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: The catalytic role provided by government, to use the Espie expression, is of course a system of tax concessions to those companies. Those are the matters which are fundamental and which seem to have been fundamentally misunderstood in the Sydney Morning Herald article.

The suggestion implicit in the Sydney Morning Herald article, and indeed in the interjection made by Senator Peter Rae, is that these things are best left to market forces. That is what we have been told for the last 10 years in Australia . No other country has seen fit to take that course in relation to the development of high technology industries. All of them have had a more successful record than Australia. If that is the view of members of the Opposition I would be pleased to hear them advocate it in public. It has not been a very successful course of development anywhere else and it would not be successful in Australia. When one looks at the situation revealed by the Espie report, I think it is very important to see what will in fact be provided in respect of high technology industries by the system the Government has adopted. We as a government look forward to this system attracting capital into high technology areas. If we can do that it will be a vast improvement on the general investment situation which obtains in Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the reported determination of the Australian Government to water down or weaken the existing policy relating to sporting contacts with South Africa. I ask: Firstly, does the Government not agree that the implementation of such a policy will dismay opponents of apartheid throughout the world unless it is accompanied by the imposition of an effective code of conduct applicable to Australian business and trading interests operating in South Africa? Secondly, will the investigations into such a code of conduct, for which I have pressed for several years and which the Foreign Minister promised to expedite in his announcement of 5 June 1983, be brought to speedy fruition so that Australia can be seen to be evenhanded and effective in its opposition to apartheid?

—I do not accept the suggestion that the Government is in any way proposing to water down its policy concerning sporting ties with South Africa. It is the case that in June the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced that Cabinet had called for a further review of the question of sporting links with South Africa. So far as I am aware, that review is still under way.
—He went further than that.
—Is Senator Missen talking about the matter of individuals?
—Codes of conduct.

—Until the results of that review are completed, I do not think it is possible for me to give a more substantial answer than that on behalf of the Minister, except to say that the Government's strong commitment to the Gleneagles declaration on apartheid and sport remains quite undiminished. It is the Government's belief that sport in South Africa continues to be manifestly subject to the inequalities of apartheid. Even though some changes may have been introduced, sport cannot be viewed in isolation. The Government is not persuaded that normal sport can take place in a thoroughly abnormal, indeed pathological, environment in that country. To the extent that other questions have been raised about codes of conduct and the like, I will refer the matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and get an early reply for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN ATOMIC ENERGY COMMISSION RESEARCH ESTABLISHMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is the Australian Atomic Energy Commission to proceed with plans to phase down research work on uranium enrichment at Lucas Heights in Sydney? To what extent do these plans affect the current research work being undertaken at Lucas Heights? Will there be an immediate termination of experimental work that has recently commenced? Will any jobs be lost at Lucas Heights through staff cuts, natural attrition or transfer, as a result of these plans? What is the likely future of Lucas Heights, which currently employs about 1,500 people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Resources and Energy and those statutory authorities under its control, of which the Australian Atomic Energy Commission is one, were obliged by preliminary decision of the Expenditure Review Committee to live within financial ceilings on expenditure this year. Those ceilings were more stringent than they otherwise would have been had we not inherited such a desperate financial situation from the irresponsible Government which preceded us and had the present Government and the public alike not been misled by the discredited former Treasurer as to the size of the impending deficit which this Government faced when it came into office.

ANSWER.PARA: Given the severe financial constraints which required the Government to impose ceilings on expenditure by the Atomic Energy Commission and any number of other government departments and statutory authorities, it was necessary to reorder the spending priorities within the Atomic Energy Commission. As a result of that reordering it was decided that the expansion of the uranium enrichment research or experimental program which had been scheduled previously would not take place . It was decided also that a somewhat greater amount than had been allocated in the previous year would be allocated for the Synroc program. Those decisions were taken by the Government in what it saw to be a responsible way and in areas which were compatible with the policy of the Australian Labor Party.

Regarding the employment of officers of the AEC, I thought the figure was somewhat below 1,500. I thought it was more like 1,200, but I am not certain of that. No jobs have been lost as a result of that reordering of priorities within the AEC, although in any year there is some attrition. I expect that there has been some attrition within the AEC this year. Returning specifically to the enrichment program which had been previously scheduled for expansion, a test bed -if I remember the correct technical term-is still being constructed or has been constructed, but the expansion of that test bed facility to what was called a cascade will not proceed, at least in this year. As to the longer term future of the Atomic Energy Commission, that is one of the matters which will be to some extent under review by the Government when the entire nuclear policy is reviewed .

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Resources and Energy agree with the statement by the Federal member for Bendigo that no decision has yet been taken by the Government on the continuation of the $80 a tonne liquefied petroleum gas subsidy beyond March 1984? If so, when will a decision be made? Was it not an election undertaking that the subsidy would continue for another three years at least?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was certainly not an election undertaking by me that the subsidy would continue for another three years at least, and I was the responsible shadow Minister at the time; nor was it, as far as I am aware, an undertaking given by anyone else in a position of responsibility in the Australian Labor Party or by any other candidate. But since I have not monitored every newspaper or listened to the broadcasts of every radio station in Australia I could not be absolutely certain about that. It is correct, as the honourable member for Bendigo is reported by Senator Scott to have stated, that no decision has yet been taken by the Government in respect of the future of the subsidy beyond 31 March 1984 when the current legislation expires.

ANSWER.PARA: One proposition which has been put to the Government, particularly by local government authorities which run, as business undertakings, reticulated gas supplies in substantial country towns and also supply bottled gas in substantial country towns and which are obliged each year to strike rates on an annual basis , is that there be more stability and predictability in price separate from the absolute level of prices. There is a budgetary problem in that the local authority must strike a rate of charges for the entire year. If the price increases substantially in mid-year those local authorities cannot in that same financial year recover the higher cost from their customers. One of the options which the Government is considering-it was originally intended that a decision would be made before the end of this calendar year but it may be deferred until early 1984-is a ceiling price proposal rather than the continuation of the subsidy in order better to accommodate the needs of the local government authorities. I add, in closing, that the discredited former Prime Minister, even though he was running amok with the cheque book in the desperate days of his final election campaign, did not promise to continue that subsidy of $80 a tonne beyond 31 March 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. What are the rules governing the granting of the special benefit to unemployed persons under 16 years of age? Is the Minister aware that some 15-year-olds without other means of support are being denied benefits?

—I will make available to Senator Zakharov and anyone else the guidelines pertaining to the granting of the special benefit to persons under 16 years of age. The benefit is available particularly to those who have, in fact, been in the work force and who qualify in terms of the stringent conditions which surround the special benefit. We have a difficult situation in this country where people of the age of 15 are permitted to leave school-sometimes at the age of 14 in many States-and yet are not provided for under the social security system. By the same token, under the laws in various States such children are considered to be legally the responsibility of their parents. It is for this reason, in addition to the fact that we do not think it is satisfactory for children from the age of 15 to the age of about 19 to have only the choice, essentially, of receiving either a job or unemployment benefit, that the Government is looking at the income support for all our young people to see whether we cannot satisfactorily rationalise the many and varied systems of payments available for income support and to see whether we cannot improve the low retention rate of these young people in our education system.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. It concerns the assets test on pensions and especially the predicament of persons who have been on invalid pensions but who, by the passage of time, become eligible for the age pension instead. Does the Minister agree that this transition at age 60 for a woman pensioner, which is a particular case that I have in mind, does not reduce the financial demands on that person because of her invalid condition? Is it not the case that such persons who have small sums invested to help meet additional medical and other costs due to their invalid condition are now to be severely penalised? Since such a person is unlikely to want to own a caravan or a boat, will the Government look carefully again at the whole structure of the assets test, perhaps on a basis which would except assets of any kind up to a certain money value? If the Minister is not prepared to do that, how does he propose to deal with the problem of the invalid aged I have mentioned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Mason for his question. Yes, I agree that when an invalid turns 60 his or her financial needs do not change. No, I do not agree that the sums invested by the lady he referred to will be, I think the term was devastated, by the assets test. Invalid pensioners will be subjected to the assets test in the same manner as age, service and widow pensioners and supporting parent beneficiaries. There will be no change in their treatment under the means test on attaining age pension age. I do not know where Senator Mason got the impression that there would be. The allowable assets limits that we have suggested, of $17,100 for a single person and $28,500 for a married couple, I believe will be adequate to meet medical and other costs due to invalidity under the existing system. They will also be assisted by the introduction of Medicare which will provide basic hospital and medical services at that time. Even beyond these limits, the pensioner entitlement reduces by $9. 60 a week for each additional $10,000 held in assessable assets-I emphasise assessable assets-so that the entitlement is in fact not completely lost until asset holdings reach over $106,000 for a single person and $177,000 for a married couple.

ANSWER.PARA: I share Senator Mason's view that invalidity or disability is a very expensive lifestyle and that there is a good argument for people who are disabled to receive either an extra payment to compensate them for the extra costs of that disability or extra provisions through the provision of aids, special accommodation, et cetera. If we are to proceed to provide that payment through a disability payment or to provide increased funds through assistance for housing and aids for disability, et cetera, we will need the funds to do so.

It is to assist this group of people-low income pensioners, low income earners in particular, those who do not have homes and those who need help in providing for themselves private rental accommodation-that we intend to introduce the reforms to recoup for the revenue the moneys that have been leached out of the system by those who have been circumventing the income test till now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of what the Minister said, and I take his point, will he answer the third part of my question? I concede the point that moneys have to be transferred, one might say, to the more needy parts of the community. I will ask the Minister the question again and I think he will see the point. Since such a person is unlikely to want to own a caravan or a boat, will the Government look carefully again at the whole structure of the assets test, perhaps on a basis which would except assets of any kind up to a certain money value? After all, the Government can still get the money diversion if it does that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. We are continuing to review our proposals for the assets test in consultation with various groups. I point out that the reason for excluding personal effects of the type Senator Mason mentioned is that to set out to assess all these personal effects, which are perhaps held in the home, and effects such as caravans and cars, would first of all provide a very large administrative problem and, secondly, be unnecessarily intrusive into persons' lives.

ANSWER.PARA: I concede that it may be a reasonable proposal to do as Senator Mason suggests and provide extra payments for those people to make up for their disability or provide an extra allowance on top of the ordinary means test or the incomes test plus assests test for those with a disability. It is a proposal which I believe should be looked at in the review of the whole area of assistance to handicapped persons and not be just picked out as an item in the specific assets test.

I point out that, at the moment, invalid pensioners are treated in exactly the same way as other pensioners. Their treatment will not be any different under the assets test from what it was under the income test. Sure, their non- assessable assets will be counted; but they will not be singled out in any way, nor will they be penalised in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and concerns the proposed Darwin-Alice Springs railway and the independent inquiry which has been set up by the Government to look into the matter. The Minister is no doubt well aware of the enormous interest in the project in my home State of South Australia and of the considerable benefits it will bring to the State in terms of employment generation and in assisting industries in the Iron Triangle region. When can we expect the inquiry to be completed? When can we anticipate a final decision to be made on whether the railway will proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Alice Springs-Darwin railway and the problems of transport generally in that region have led to a number of questions being raised during the early session of this Parliament, as well as in this second session. I have indicated the Government's commitment to a considerable improvement in transport and communications generally in that region. Senator Foreman asked about the inquiry which the Commonwealth Government has initiated as a result of representations made to it by the Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, who has expressed a more than average interest in assisting both the Northern Territory Government and the Australian Government to expedite that rail link and look at the problems of transport generally within the region. Negotiations between the Commonwealth and the South Australian and Northern Territory governments are proceeding to establish terms of reference acceptable to the Commonwealth and those two other governments. When those terms of reference are finally agreed to , the inquiry will proceed with a view to the Commonwealth assisting in the provision of that very important facility.

ANSWER.PARA: I reiterate what I said on the last occasion: The Commonwealth does not resile from its responsibility to provide this rail service but, having regard to the tight monetary position we were in and the deficit which the Government inherited, there had to be a rearranging of priorities concerning the provision of funds. Consequently, a proposition was put to the Northern Territory Government that it bear part of the cost of providing this important and essential rail link. That was rejected by the Northern Territory Government. The South Australian Government then expressed some interest in the project. So we are talking about an inquiry and a project which will involve three governments. I give the honourable senator an assurance that when the terms of reference are agreed to and negotiations have proceeded substantially in that area-agreement, I think, has almost been reached-the inquiry will proceed with the view of meeting the Government's fundamental commitment to that rail link. Of course, the contributions by the other governments will be an important part of that inquiry.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: PROFITS FROM SALE OF NEW SOUTH WALES LOTTERY TICKETS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government. I refer to the agreement which was negotiated between the former Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, and the New South Wales Government that from the net profits of the sale of New South Wales lottery tickets in the Australian Capital Territory 50 per cent would be paid to the Territory and credited to the Community Development Fund. Is the Minister aware that the agreement expired on 30 June 1983? Is the Minister taking steps to renew the agreement and will any new agreement operate from 1 July 1983, or will there be a loss of revenue to the Australian Capital Territory because of the failure to renew the agreement?

—That question involves an amount of detail which I am afraid I am not in possession of. I will certainly refer the matter to the Minister whom I represent in this place and give an early reply to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it still a fact that Commonwealth money has not yet started flowing to Tasmania to compensate for the stopping of the Gordon below Franklin Dam? Is this because the State Government is still refusing to sign the financial agreement? I ask whether the Minister is aware of Mr Gray's comments this morning, in relation to the Tasmanian Government:

QUESTION.PARA: We've kept everyone in employment, we've paid for those people to be employed and we've done it so far without Commonwealth assistance.
I ask whether Mr Gray went on to say:
. . . I'm just a little bit intrigued as to why people like Senator Coates and Mr Wriedt and a few other people are so anxious that the State puts its signature to this agreement.

Is Mr Gray putting off signing just so that he can say these things without acknowledging that this situation is only temporary? Is he able to do so only because of reliance on the Commonwealth's promise, or is he perhaps dishonestly trying to show that the Commonwealth is not fulfilling its part of the bargain?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable senator rephrase the last portion of his question, bearing in mind standing order 418.

—Is Mr Gray perhaps trying to show that the Commonwealth is not fulfilling its part of the bargain? Alternatively, do Mr Gray's statements mean that the State Government does not really want or need the promised Commonwealth funds at all?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Two-thirds of that question-the latter part-was out of order. I suggest that you should rule it out of order. It can be rephrased into a proper question, but how could the Minister possibly give an answer as to what might be in the mind of the Premier of Tasmania or of anybody else? That is what the question asks for an answer to.
—Mr President, on the point of order, it may be that the Minister has information communicated directly to him from Mr Gray of which neither Senator Rae is aware, nor am I aware.
—I will allow the question insofar as Senator Walsh is able to answer it, bearing in mind his ministerial responsibility as the Minister representing the Treasurer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what is in the mind of Mr Gray, because apart from any other problem, what he has in his mind appears to keep changing. In the middle of June he said that $30m had already been spent on the Gordon below Franklin dam; the next week he said the figure was $60m, and the day after that it was $65m. Apart from the innate problem of lacking the psychic powers to delve into the mind of the Tasmanian Premier, I have an additional complication in that what comes out of his mouth keeps changing.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the main point of Senator Coates's question, I understand that on the day of the High Court judgment the Prime Minister, I think it was, wrote a letter offering assistance for some job creation projects in Tasmania. He sought an interim agreement between the Commonwealth and the State which would regularise the transfer of Commonwealth funds to the State to pay for those alternative employment projects. Certainly on 31 August the Prime Minister when he visited Tasmania, following quite extensive consultations between State and Commonwealth officials, gave a draft agreement to the Tasmanian Premier who, I understand, indicated that, having had a look at the agreement, he would sign it within 14 days. He still has not done so. He received that letter 20 or 21 days ago. I was advised as recently as noon today that he still has not signed that agreement. So if the Tasmanian Premier has not received any money from the Commonwealth to fulfil the costs of the projects which the Commonwealth has agreed to fund, he has nobody to blame but himself. The Commonwealth agreed to fund projects to a total cost, in round figures, of $25m. It appears that what the Tasmanian Premier wants is not an interim agreement which would regularise the interim payment of Commonwealth funds to a State, which is what is done in every other case that I have ever heard of, but a brown paper bag stuffed full of used $50 notes or something of that irregular order. This Government does not operate in that way and will not operate in that way.

I note also that in his most recent comments on the subject, the Tasmanian Premier indicated his intention to build a coal-fired power station which, I note, is a complete repudiation of everything he said about Tasmania's future power needs as early as February and March this year. That demonstrates further difficulties in my attempting to delve into what is in his mind because, as I said earlier, whatever may be in his mind, different things keep coming out of his mouth. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFIT: PAYMENT TO RUNAWAY CHILDREN

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security seen the article in the Press last Sunday which claimed that the Department of Social Security was handing out unemployment benefit to young runaway children? What action is taken to ensure that the social security system is not misused?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did see the article in the Sunday Press which claimed that two runway children had claimed unemployment benefit from the Griffith, New South Wales, office of the Department of Social Security. The article suggested, in part, that such claimants are not required to present proof of identity and that inquiries into their family circumstances are not made. The article, of course, did not give any surnames or details of the people involved. If it had, in any circumstance section 17 of the Social Security Act would prevent me or anyone else from giving details of individuals' circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: All I can say is that to qualify for unemployment benefit a person must be at least 16 years of age, be unemployed, be capable and willing to undertake suitable work and be looking for such work. The person is also required to have registered for work with the Commonwealth Employment Service before claiming benefit, and payment is not made until satisfactory documentary proof of identity is provided. Where persons cannot properly identify themselves the Department will assist them to do so. If hardship is being experienced, the payment of a special benefit may be made in the meantime.

As the law provides for payment of benefit to persons 16 years and over who meet the criteria, the Department would not normally, under these circumstances, make inquiries about whether such a person is a runaway. If the person is under 16 years of age inquiries would normally be made of the State welfare authorities and, where appropriate and possible, the child's parents. As I said earlier in answer to, I think, Senator Zakharov payments to persons under 16 years of age are not made where adequate assistance is available for a child and , particularly in this case, where adequate or extra assistance has been provided from State authorities.

So I find it hard to accept the article on face value. I find it hard to understand how two children, bearing in mind all of those provisions of the legislation and the actions provided for under the legislation, could in fact have got unemployment benefit at that age without providing identity, et cetera, and without a fairly elaborate fraud being perpetrated. However, I will seek from the Department information as to what may have happened. If Senator Childs or anyone else has any other details about the case, they would certainly assist .

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that a Commonwealth medical benefit is at present not payable in respect of health screening tests? —I thought it was fairly sexist of Senator Haines to suggest that it is only men who sometimes cannot control their sexual urges. She raises two problems. The first is the limitation on provision of Commonwealth benefits for screening tests. Senator Haines well knows that that provision was introduced because of the indiscriminate screening tests which were being performed by various clinics as a result of the previous liberal application of the legislation and the system. Whole football teams were going in for all sorts of tests and doctors in cohoots with various clinics were organising screening tests which cost several hundred dollars when the chances of picking up any diseases were in fact quite minimal. The situation of prostitutes and sexually transmitted diseases to which Senator Haines referred is a different one. In that case, the screening test is a fairly limited one. There is a provision in the legislation-I am sure it is still there but I will check with the Minister for Health in case it is not-for items for the detection of sexually transmitted diseases through pathological and other tests. However, I think in most cases people indulging in that profession would have been advised to take out medical insurance to cover such tests, which I would have thought were a necessary part of their occupation. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The prevarication of the Government, and the Prime Minister in particular, over uranium policy.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition brings before the Senate this matter which I think it can be clearly demonstrated is a matter of public importance. It certainly can be very clearly demonstrated that the Government and in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are prevaricating over their uranium policy. That is a matter of great importance. It is a matter of great importance to the State of South Australia, to Australia and to the companies which are involved in the search for and the exploitation of our uranium resources. I suppose the immediate importance of the subject is best highlighted by reference to what is happening in South Australia and in particular what is happening at Roxby Downs. Currently in that State a major feasibility study is being conducted on what is to be a very large mine. Current indications are that we have a major mineral deposit. The people who are seeking to exploit it have publicly claimed it to be the largest deposit of its type yet discovered. It contains uranium, gold and copper. They describe it as being a project which will involve $1400m investment, new industry worth $500m per year, thousands of jobs to construct it, 10,000 new permanent jobs to run and support it, and jobs for hundreds of years. That is the self-assessment of that project. I have seen no outside criticism of those claims. Indeed, all of the evidence that I have seen is that we have here a major Australian asset which it is in Australia's interest to develop.

SPEECH.PARA: The participants in this project have already spent very large sums of money. They have spent, for example, nearly $2m on environmental studies, and millions are currently being expended on a pilot plant. By the end of the feasibility stage the participants expect to have expended some $150m before they get to the point of making a final decision to proceed. So even at the exploration and feasibility stage this is a very substantial project.

It is not, however, only South Australia which is involved in the development of uranium. In the Northern Territory we have the ongoing mines at Ranger and Nabarlek which are currently producing. We have the potential for other producers. Each of the two operating mines in the Northern Territory has the capacity to expand sales. Each of them wants to sell. Currently the Government is either unwilling or unable to tell the developers of these projects where they stand. Currently the Government and in particular the Prime Minister are prevaricating over where these projects can go. In the case of Roxby Downs, there is even prevarication about whether the project can go ahead at all. That matter is of concern to the Opposition and I believe to many Australians. It is a position which is totally unsatisfactory.

This debate, like any other debate which touches on the issue of uranium development, is likely to be diverted by the Government and some other honourable senators up a series of blind alleys. Smokescreens will be raised and the central issues will, if possible, be avoided. I am sure that issues such as safeguards, waste disposal, nuclear weapons proliferation, Aboriginals and the environment are likely to be raised in debate which at this stage, in the Opposition's view, should be centred upon the prevarication of the Government and on its failure to come to grips with policy in this area.

I make it quite plain that, as far as the Opposition is concerned, all of those issues which I have mentioned are important. Of course, it is important to have appropriate safeguards policies. We are to be concerned about waste disposal; we are to be concerned about the extraordinary question of nuclear weapons proliferation and how we can minimise the dangers of nuclear war; and of course we must have policies which protect the proper interests of Aboriginals and the proper interests of the Australian environment. Indeed, in my most recent visit to South Australia, and to the Chamber of Mines, at its invitation I addressed the question of Aboriginal mining interests and how they are to be brought together.

I will not have it said, Mr Deputy President, that there is any lack of interest or concern on the part of the Opposition about these matters. I mention this because that allegation is a common feature of these debates. For example, I think Senator Tate suggested a careless approach on the part of the Opposition when last we debated this subject. I simply remind the Senate that when the Fraser Government took the decision in 1977 that we would proceed to develop Australia's uranium reserves, the Government assessed most carefully all of the relevant areas of policy. I refer members of the Senate to Parliamentary Paper No. 198 of 1977 in which the issues that I have mentioned are all dealt with in some detail. I remind the Senate that in this area the previous Government was careful to ensure that the conditions on which Australia entered into the world trade in uranium and the conditions on which we became part of the peaceful development of nuclear energy were very properly laid down. The Government regarded all of those matters seriously. That has been done. It may well be that some of those matters will be further refined and defined but the fact is that six years ago Australia's Government took the decision that it could, on a responsible basis, participate in this important element of world trade and make an important contribution to the world's energy resources.

Mr Deputy President, in 1983 this debate takes place in the context of a series of facts which make it clear that Australia should continue to develop its uranium. We have around the world the widespread use of nuclear power for electricity generation, with an unrivalled safety record when compared with other forms of electricity generation. I name just a few of the countries that use nuclear power. In Finland in 1982, 40.3 per cent of electricity was generated by nuclear power; in Sweden, the figure was 39 per cent; in France, 38 .7 per cent; in Switzerland, 28.2 per cent; in Belgium, 27.7 per cent; and in Bulgaria, 25 per cent. The list goes on but the fact is that a large slice of the world is now getting a substantial part of its electricity from nuclear power. We live in a world which is continually developing waste disposal techniques, and those techniques are safely in use in user countries. We live in a world which, unhappily, has a nuclear arsenal which has been detailed on many occasions in this place by Senator Chipp and others. That arsenal is in existence and it will remain whatever Australia does, but we do seek to control and diminish it through our participation in the United Nations Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.

It is usual in this debate for allegations to be made that to sell uranium is to be like a drug pusher-that it is like selling heroin. Reference is made to the problem of nuclear war. I simply say to those who advance that argument that they should consider the deaths caused by so many aspects of our normal life. For example, if we consider coal mining we find that, during 1982, 1,662 deaths occurred as a result of that activity. If we consider the motor vehicle, which is so central a part of our normal life, we can find thousands of deaths resulting from its use. Yet we do not accuse coal miners and the manufacturers of motor cars of engaging in the drug trade. That sort of hyperbole gets us nowhere. The fact of the matter is that Australia is in the nuclear trade. It is engaged in that trade on a basis which adds to the safeguards in the world; it does not detract from them. The removal of Australia from that scene would not make any difference to the issues which are properly brought before the Senate by many honourable senators. It would not make any difference to the availability of uranium for warlike purposes. Thus, the argument is largely irrelevant to the issues that lie before us.

It is important to remember that the alternative methods of electricity generation which are available produce their own problems. I think Senator Collard, who will be speaking on behalf of the Opposition later in this debate, will make a number of comments in that regard. But it is important to note that the use of coal for power generation involves massive mining. It involves the massive generation of waste products, both solid and atmospheric. It also gives rise to difficult environmental issues such as acid rain. When one compares all these things with the safety record of nuclear generation of electricity, the arguments get into some more reasonable focus.

It might be argued that we should go totally away from all these forms of energy generation, be they coal or uranium, and move to things like hydro power. I remind the Senate of the passion with which the development of hydro power has been opposed in this place, not least by the Australian Democrats because they see the despoliation of the environment as being so important. There are disadvantages in every form of power generation. It is ludicrous to turn our backs on the fact that so much of the world has realised that uranium has its part to play. I refer honourable senators to the debate which took place on this issue a week or two ago and to the extensive quotations from some notable Australians, including the late Sir Barton Pope, Sir Macfarlane Burnet and Sir Mark Oliphant, all of whom spoke of the long term needs of Australia to develop its uranium resources. Those quotations were read into the record by, I think, Senator Townley. They are a good reminder to Australians of the positive need to develop our uranium resources.

All the things I have mentioned are part of the context in which we chide the Government for its prevarication. I remind honourable senators that there is an existing industry in Australia which the Government will allow to proceed. There are controls in place in all the areas of concern. The Labor Government appears to be moving towards the approval of the largest mine, namely Roxby Downs, although that is not certain from the statements that have been made by Senator Walsh and others. I remind the Senate of the potential which exists, according to the Government's own papers, to increase substantially-indeed, some say to treble-our exports in this area. I remind the Senate of the costly work which is proceeding with the approval of the State Labor Government in South Australia and of the jobs that are to be created in this industry.

Having reminded the Senate of those matters, I turn to what Labor is doing in this area. One might have thought that a party which is so interested in seeing its policy established by the grass roots, as is the Labor Party, would have in its policy document a sensible statement regarding its policy in government. But the printed policy which is issued by the Party demonstrates simply a hole. It demonstrates a desperate attempt to compromise between the competing factions in the Labor Party. It has produced a confusion of words which was described, I think by a newspaper today, as a gap waiting for a policy to fill. But there are some very sobering words in the printed policy of the Labor Party which would suggest that the Labor Government might take a quite strong stance, one more akin to that of the Australian Democrats than the words of the Prime Minister, which I will give the Senate, would suggest. The policy statement says that a Labor government will:

declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia; repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor Government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium; and not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium pursuant to agreements entered into contrary to ALP policy.
Later it states:

understanding the difficulties which could be encountered in the implementation of that commitment our uranium position would be a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry and that certain conditions as outlined will and must be applied to those mines existing in production as of July 1982; and as an ALP government we give total commitment to preventing any new mines from being developed during our period of office.
Then over the page one finds what most people regard as the Roxby Downs exception. It states that the Government will:

consider applications for the export of uranium mined incidentally to the mining of other minerals on a case by case basis and on the criteria of whether in the opinion of a Labor government the mining of such minerals is in the national interest;

That is a mishmash. It is very hard to get any clear guide from the policy of the Labor Party as to just where it stands. I know that a lot of businessmen and people who believe that it is in Australia's interest to mine uranium were greatly heartened when in Sydney, on about 2 September-not very long ago-the Prime Minister made one of his characteristically unequivocal declarations of support of the interests of the group he happened to be addressing. He made it very clear to them. He told the inaugural lunch of the Business Council of Australia:
. . . as far as our Government is concerned, the Federal Government, and the Government of South Australia, the Roxby development is going ahead, and nothing is going to stop that.
He went on:
I say that together with John Bannon, who authorises me to speak for him.

So, to the pleasure of the Opposition and to the approval of all of those who see this as being in Australia's national interest, we had that very clear statement on the part of the Prime Minister in Sydney just a few weeks ago. Again to a business audience, as reported in the Business Review Weekly of 3 September to 9 September, at page 13, we find similar statements by the Prime Minister that there is going to be no problem about Roxby Downs and that there is going to be no problem about extending new contracts to Nabarlek and to Ranger.

So there was an appearance at the beginning of this month that the Labor Party had made up its mind. There was an appearance that these important Australian projects were going to be allowed to proceed. The Prime Minister's words in Sydney were as clear as they could be. Of course we are used to a Prime Minister who goes to America and says apparently what the Americans want to hear, and goes to Indonesia and says what the Indonesians want to hear. Indeed he seems to have the characteristics of a chameleon rather that a statesman. We find that on 6 September, within a week of those forthright Sydney statements, Mr Anthony addressed a question to Mr Hawke in the Parliament. There, of course, Mr Hawke was answering in front of his own troops, none of whom wishes to be part of this debate because of the rank division among them on this issue. I refer to House of Representatives Hansard of 6 September 1983, page 369, when Mr Hawke suddenly became all equivocal. I quote in part from his answer:

It is well known that Roxby Downs also has major deposits of copper and gold. It is one of the world's major underdeveloped mineral resources. All honourable members will appreciate that Roxby Downs is of particular significance to the economy of South Australia as well as to the Australian economy as a whole.
He went on:

In the context of this policy on existing mines-and Roxby Downs-the Government is currently undertaking a review of all aspects of the industry, including the international safeguards aspects. The review will be considered by the parliamentary Party in the near future. Any continuing exports will be on the strictest conditions and will be undertaken in the light of the considerations that I have put forward.

On the same day I asked Senator Walsh, who is the responsible Minister in this place, whether the views put forward by the Prime Minister and reported in the Business Review Weekly-the views I have just referred to-were the views of the Government. I asked whether Mr Hawke's remarks had pre-empted the Government's uranium policy review. Senator Walsh said-I quote his answer in part:

. . . it has been widely publicised over some time-a number of submissions have been prepared or are in the process of being prepared for lodgment with Cabinet for discussion and subsequent decision, probably some time later this month, regarding the mining of uranium within Australia, and matters directly associated with it, and the international safeguards agreement. I will refer that . . . question . . . to the Prime Minister . . . to see whether he has anything to add to my answer.

Senator Walsh, who always seems to pride himself on his forthright approach to economic and other matters, slid off that question. I refer honourable senators to the record if they have any doubt about it. In exactly the same way, when questioned by Senator Sir John Carrick during the examination by Senate Estimates Committee C on 12 September, Senator Walsh slid about but in the end he said:
This is clearly a policy matter. I have answered the question about three or four times already. There is that presumption around-
that is the presumption that Roxby Downs will proceed-
based on various people's interpretations of what is in the Labor Party's platform. But that is part of the comprehensive policy review decision.

Nothing is clearer than that this Government does not have a policy on uranium. It is clear from Senator Walsh's statements in the Estimates Committee and elsewhere that there is no ongoing commitment to Roxby Downs, notwithstanding the Roxby exception in the policy. Nothing is clear about the policy except that it does not exist. The current stories in all the media about Labor's further shilly-shallying on this subject all highlight the failure of this Government and the failure of Mr Hawke in particular to live up to their obligations to the Australian people, to clarify this policy and to allow Australians to get on with developing Australia's resources. One can have some respect for Senator Chipp and for the Australian Democrats, who say: 'We will oppose uranium mining and export under any conditions'; one can have no respect for a government which behaves in this shilly-shallying way, which cannot make up its mind and which puts its internal conflicts over dogma ahead of Australia's national interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Firstly, I would like to make a few comments on Senator Chaney's remarks. Senator Chaney said, if I got it down correctly, that Roxby Downs is the largest deposit of gold, copper, silver and uranium in the world. He made this statement not in respect of each of the minerals separately but collectively. That is not, strictly speaking, correct. One can argue that the largest deposit of those minerals, and almost any mineral one can think of, is in the ocean. While that seems to be irrelevant, it draws attention to a very important point-that the absolute size of the deposit, the magnitude of the reserves of valuable minerals in a deposit, does not tell us whether it is economic, with present technology, to mine that deposit. I suggest that Roxby Downs must, as yet, be regarded as being in that category.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney said that the company concerned with Roxby Downs was going through the feasibility stage-I think that was the term he used-of its study. Implicit in the use of the term 'feasibility stage' is not only technical feasibility of mining the deposit-that, of course, is beyond doubt. It is, as I pointed out last week among other things, technically feasible to grow pineapples in Antarctica. It is technically feasible to extract uranium from sea -water; it is technically feasible to extract gold from sea-water; it is technically feasible to extract almost every element found in the world from sea -water. Whether, however, it is economically viable to do so may be a completely different question. The companies which are involved in Roxby Downs have yet to assess the economic feasibility of that project. For that reason, among others, no formal application has been lodged, so far as I know, either with the South Australian Government for a production licence or with this Government for guarantees of export permits for uranium or any of the other minerals which are located in that ore body.

Senator Chaney was objective enough-I give him credit for this-to mention clause 64c of the Australian Labor Party's minerals and energy platform, which I incorrectly called clause 11c in a similar debate a couple of weeks ago. Clause 64c, to which he referred, is the Roxby Downs clause. Although Roxby Downs is not mentioned in that clause, it is, so far as I know, unanimously accepted by people who participated in the last National Conference of the Labor Party, during which that clause was written into the platform that Roxby Downs was the prime example of an ore body in which uranium might be incidental to the recovery of other minerals.

I wish to say a few words about Nabarlek, Ranger and other potential mines. If there were no political constraints, no environmental concerns and no weapons proliferation concerns-in other words, if a government were determining a policy based on maximising the net economic benefit to the country and determining a uranium policy based only on that criterion-the cheapest way of supplying the quantities of uranium which could be sold at acceptable prices on world markets from Australian sources for the rest of this decade would be to expand the production capacity of Ranger. So at least for the foreseeable future, and using economic criteria alone, there is no justification for the production to be drawn from other mines for the amounts of uranium for which sales can reasonably be expected for the rest of this decade. I do not recall the precise figures but they are something of this order of magnitude: For an additional investment of $ 70m, an extra 3,000 tonnes of yellowcake could be produced from the existing Ranger mine; to produce an equivalent quantity from the next best alternative requires a capital investment of the order of $350m or $400m. So on cost effective grounds alone, if there were to be an expansion of uranium production for a number of years, the economically rational thing to do would be to supply that increased demand from the Ranger mine.

But having said that, I think it is equally important to note that at this stage there is no possibility of contracts being written at acceptable prices for further supplies. I cite a letter from Queensland Mines Ltd dated 17 January this year:

. . . the uranium industry is experiencing extremely difficult times and the opinion of most experts is that the market will remain depressed for at least another four, possibly eight years with a consequential decline in prices.

More recently, in a letter dated 30 March-after the Federal election-a letter from the Total group of companies, which has an interest in the prospect at Ben Lomond adjacent to Townsville in Queensland, stated:

At present, of course, there would be no question of a mining development because of the state of the world market for both molybdenum and uranium, even if it were decided that this particular deposit met the Government's guidelines for development.

I repeat the words 'even if it were decided that this particular deposit met the Government's guidelines for development'. In other words, at this stage there is no reason to rush into a hasty decision.

As further confirmation of the depressed state of the world market, although going back marginally further in time, it is known, and I have stated it in the Senate on at least two occasions, that a draft contract with the Central Electricity Generating Board of the United Kingdom and the Pancontinental venturers in Australia-the Jabiluka prospect in Australia-was put before the previous Minister responsible, Mr Anthony, who rejected it on the grounds that the pricing arrangements were not satisfactory. This fact was acknowledged and published on 5 May this year in the Australian in the following terms:

A spokesman for the former trade and resources minister, Mr Doug Anthony, confirmed this, but said that it should be made clear that the refusal was based on lack of suitable provision for future price reviews.

In other words, in Mr Anthony's judgment, the price offered in the first year for that contract was satisfactory on purely commercial criteria but the price likely to be obtained in subsequent years was not. Of course, if one is looking at a 20-year contract, obviously the price obtained in the first year is relatively unimportant. The previous Government rejected that application because the price was not satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that Jabiluka?

—Yes, it was Jabiluka. It is granted-Senator Chaney was reasonably objective about this and I am willing to be likewise-that there has been a marginal improvement in the spot market price of uranium since Mr Anthony rejected that provisional application last December. But it has not improved to the point where contracts could be written at prices which would have been acceptable to the previous Government. It is a subterfuge to suggest, as the Opposition did a fortnight ago in moving, of all things, a motion of urgency and in a slightly varied form repeated the boring procedure today, that there is something reprehensible about this or that this Government is prevaricating because it has not yet made decisions in detail on a policy as important as the mining of uranium in Australia and the conditions, if any, under which it will be supplied to potential customers.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken the trouble to have the meaning of the word 'prevarication' looked up for me. It means to speak or act evasively, to quibble or equivocate and to straddle. Straddle seems to be a very accurate description of the Liberal Party and of what the Liberal Party and National Party between them are doing about another piece of legislation presently before the Senate. I refer to Senator Ryan's Sex Discrimination Bill. Mr Macphee has said that there is no place in the Liberal Party for anyone who opposes it. Of course, Senator Walters opposes it quite vociferously, saying that women are as smart as men. No enlightened person, on average, would dispute that. Whether Senator Walters makes the average is something on which one may have reservations.

To return to the subject before the Senate, it is not reasonable to assert that this Government is prevaricating on this issue. What is reasonable is to assert that this Government, in contradistinction to its predecessor, is behaving responsibly. When the coalition parties were in government, on some issues they rarely prevaricated. Sometimes they did but more often than not the Liberal Party just caved in and did what the National Party told it to do. There is no haste needed in making a decision on this issue because on commercial grounds alone the markets are not available. In March, shortly after the election of this Government, the things which were urgent and which needed to be done were done almost immediately. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) ordered a comprehensive review of safeguards. Shortly afterwards he appointed an Ambassador for Disarmament. The Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) almost immediately cancelled the negotiating determinations which had been issued by his predecessor to six companies. I note, consistent with what I have said before, that it had issued negotiating determinations for prospects and companies and a potential supply vastly in excess of that which could be absorbed on the market if commercial criteria alone were applied.

To have issued six negotiating determinations in the way that Mr Anthony did was an irresponsible and rather foolish action. Those negotiating determinations were promptly cancelled by the present Minister for Trade who subsequently-this is already a matter of public record-reissued two of the negotiating determinations to two ventures, Nabarlek and Ranger. He has observed since that, even if commercial criteria which have been common to this and the previous Government are fulfilled, which is highly unlikely, the issuing of the determinations does not necessarily mean that approval for sales contracts will automatically be granted. That was one of the urgent matters to which this Government promptly addressed itself. I will come to others in a moment.

This Government also suspended, though not quite so quickly, the shipment of uranium to France which was scheduled for July this year. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has announced that all shipments to France are suspended until October 1984, the reason being that this Government regards the behaviour of France in detonating and testing atomic weapons in the South Pacific as unacceptable, not an act in which a civilised responsible power should indulge and one which is viewed with sufficient gravity to have led the Government to suspend shipments of uranium to that country. I guess one could say that the question of sales to France was something on which the Liberal and National parties when in government did not prevaricate. They were quite happy to supply uranium to France and to have Australian uranium used to manufacture atomic weapons to be detonated in the South Pacific, in spite of the fierce and totally justified opposition from almost every island state in the South Pacific, from New Zealand and now from Australia under the present Government. But the previous Government did not prevaricate about that. It was quite happy to supply uranium to France from which that country could construct atomic weapons for detonation in the South Pacific.

Another matter was not mentioned by Senator Chaney, but I anticipate it is likely to be mentioned by subsequent speakers in the debate; so I will say something now about the question of the change of time-table for the consideration of the whole range of submissions on the uranium issue which have been prepared by various Ministers for the Government and ultimately for consideration by Cabinet. There are some five submissions in total. At any time it would have been difficult or potentially difficult for adequate consideration to be given to that number of submissions on matters of such importance in a week when Parliament was sitting and there were many other competing demands on the time and attention of Ministers. At most times, had it been possible to complete proper consideration of those submissions during the sitting week, consideration could have been extended beyond the sitting week. But this week the Government is in the situation where the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who plays a key role in this matter, both in his capacity as being ministerially responsible for the safeguards agreement and as a senior member of the Cabinet, is leaving the country on Thursday. It would have been unwise to have reached a final decision on all these submissions in the absence of the Foreign Minister. In a parliamentary sitting week it would have been a risk to attempt to devote the time and attention that was due to this very important matter. For that reason, of course, the consideration of these submissions has been deferred until a date in October.

In closing, I point out that this is a rather tiresome rerun of the farce in which we were forced to participate 13 days ago. The Government is not prevaricating on this issue. The Government is behaving responsibly. It is giving this important, complex and admittedly for large sections of the community, somewhat emotive and potentially divisive issue-I use the term ' divisive' in the context of Australian society as a whole-the consideration which is due to it. We will not be stampeded into a hasty decision which the Government and the nation ultimately might regret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest-I even hope- that in his enthusiasm to raise this matter of public importance the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) has had a semantic problem. The matter of public importance proposed for discussion is:

SPEECH.PARA: The prevarication of the Government, and the Prime Minister in particular, over uranium policy.

I would have thought that the word 'prevarication' is basically a euphemism for lying which, I think, would be an unduly harsh term to use in this regard. The Australian Democrats agree wholehartedly that the equivocation of the Government over uranium policy is a matter of immense public importance. We think the term 'equivocation' is hard enough on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government without accusing them of lying over this matter.

The Australian Labor Party's commendable uranium policy was one of the main reasons for its election to government in March this year. There is no doubt about that at all. Its policy does outline, in no uncertain terms, the APL's total opposition to the mining, processing and export of Australian uranium. I will quote again-I think it has to be quoted frequently to remind everybody of these points-part of the ALP's uranium platform upon which it was indeed elected to office. It states:

. . . having regard to the present unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium and the development of nuclear power, and in particular-
a to the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war; and
b the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes to ensure that any danger posed by such wastes to human life and the environment is eliminated;
It is imperative that no commitment of Australia's uranium deposits to the world 's nuclear fuel cycle should be made until-
a a reasonable time has elapsed for full public debate on, and consideration of , the issues;
b the ALP is satisfied that the abovementioned problems have been solved;
Accordingly, a Labor government will-
54 a declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;
b repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor Government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium; and
c not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium pursuant to agreements entered into contrary to ALP policy.

The Australian Democrats are in entire agreement with this policy. We find it impossible to reconcile these sentiments with the actions of the Labor Government in relation to the Australian uranium industry.

The Government began its term in office well enough by cancelling negotiations for further leases for the mining of uranium in Australia. It is unfortunate that this strong stand has not been carried on. Two uranium negotiating licences have been re-issued-that of Energy Resources of Australia Ltd for the Ranger mine and that of Queensland Mines Ltd for the Nabarlek mine. It is interesting to note that although Queensland Mines Ltd may be pleading hardship because its stockpiled uranium, already mined at Nabarlek, is as yet unsold, this excuse cannot possibly be used in defence of the decision to renew ERA's licence because all production from the Ranger mine has been sold and the mine is making about $50m a year. It appears that the only reasons ERA has for wishing to negotiate further are to increase its already considerable profits and to assure customers that there will be no supply problems through the 1980s and the 1990s.

In relation to the firm undertaking that no new mines will be developed, the Australian Democrats are most concerned that the ALP apparently does not consider Roxby Downs to be a uranium mine, although reliable estimates set the amount of recoverable uranium in the mining area at about 1.2 million tonnes which is far more than the combined reserves of all other uranium mines in Australia. Indeed, it is one of the largest deposits of uranium in the world. We find it a cloud cuckoo land type of situation, an unreal situation. The Government says that because of the fact that, by accident, other minerals are present it is not a uranium mine and that it is perfectly all right to mine and process uranium. I do not know of any mine in the world which does not have a mix of elements in the ore. Nature did not design this planet so that there would be pure uranium in one place, pure copper in another place and pure gold in another place. It is a ludicrous policy, one which does not even bear a moment's examination. It is the lamest possible excuse that the Government could have for saying that this is the reason for going on with that kind of mining. Therefore, we find it absolutely incredible that the Labor Government is prepared to allow this huge new mine to proceed, apparently with a clear conscience, although it is patently obvious to anyone who has an interest in the subject that, in doing so, the Government is making complete nonsense of its own uranium policy.

I must agree with Senator Chaney to the extent that the Government is in tatters on this matter. It is all very well for the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), a responsible Minister in this Government, to get up here in this place and tell us that the Government does not intend to be stampeded into deciding this, that or the other. But the issues are plain enough . Everybody knows what the situation is concerning uranium. The state of the market, the dangers and all the other issues involved are clear enough.
