Those factors will not change between now and October or November as Senator Walsh said. He is creating a situation in Australia and the world in which we appear to be shilly-shallying and equivocating shamefully over this matter which is a matter of great importance to the community and is one which people from all sides of the community want to see solved one way or another so that at least we have a policy with which we can live. It is not good enough for the Government merely to stall on this matter because there is no reason to suppose that any new element will change the situation in the next few months or years.

I speak now about what appears to me to be an intolerable sell-out which is contemplated by the Government. I hope the Government will re-think its stand on the Kakadu National Park. Reports in the newspapers have suggested that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Cohen, is in favour of declaring the proposed Stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park a conservation zone-whatever that might be. I gather that it is an area in which uranium mining and exploration would be allowed. The Minister has made faint protesting noises about those reports but he has not denied them. I think the time has come when people all over Australia are waiting for him to deny that so that we know that this great national park will be allowed to remain intact. I am referring to that section of land between the present Kakadu National Park and the sea. It is an enormously valuable tourist and environmental asset for Australia. It is a wilderness area in a world which is increasingly losing its wilderness areas. This equivocation over the declaration of Stage 2 of Kakadu National Park is being carried out in circumstances-Senator Walsh himself has described them-in which we cannot sell any more uranium for years, maybe not even for decades.

What possible excuse can there be for not declaring Stage 2 of the park now? Once Stage 2 is declared, the park can be developed to the extent that it needs developing. Tourists can visit the area and people all over the world will say: 'Here is this marvellous place in Australia which we can visit. It is completely unspoiled wilderness country. Let us go there to see it'. Of course they will come, because wilderness areas elsewhere in the world are already grossly overcrowded. It is necessary for what remains to be preserved in world planetary terms alone. In other words, what I am saying is that it is a sound economic proposition for us to declare Stage 2 of the park and to allow it to proceed as a national park which people can visit rather than allow ourselves to be conned by the present uranium miners saying 'We want to have areas in which we can get in and meddle, explore and damage the territories'-even exploration damages the environment tremendously-'and if we find uranium we want it excised from the park. We want to go on digging up uranium all over the place'.

There are the strongest possible reasons for the world to repudiate nuclear technology completely. In the first place, every watt of electric power now being generated in the world by nuclear powerhouses could be replaced by a sensible program of power conservation, including insulation and devices which reduce the power demand of electric motors. Indeed there is the sheer waste of electric power which occurs wherever nuclear power is produced. This phenomenon of waste, such as the leaving on of building lights all night and the overuse of heating and refrigeration, is now a recognised characteristic in areas served by nuclear powerhouses. The power generated by a nuclear powerhouse is so great and its costs so huge that the incentive is to promote use rather than conservation, even up to and beyond the point of waste. So the argument that the world cannot do without nuclear power is a spurious one. The world can do without it very easily indeed. A decent program of conservation, introduced internationally tomorrow, could replace all the power now being generated by all the nuclear powerhouses in the world.

Very promising new methods of generating power cheaply are being developed rapidly and successfully. The new type of amorphous silicone cell, which converts light directly to electric power, is one. Developers in both the United States of America and Japan predict that within five years it will be cheaper than power generated by nuclear or fossil fuels. This development, which may well end up simply as rolls of plastic film which generate power when exposed to light, will provide cheap power where it is needed and will reduce, and indeed eliminate, reticulation costs and reticulation loss of power which are big factors in Australia. Importantly, these amorphous cells have a photo-electric effect-that is, the conversion is from light to power. Because of this these cells can be used in cooler and low sunlight areas and still produce electric power.

These and ancilliary developments, such as successful and cheap wind power in the form of wind farms, are suited to very cold and windy climates. Such a plant in the megawatt range has been operating at Tvind in Jutland for many years now and very successfully. It has a most interesting power curve. The power curve goes up with necessity. As the wind gets colder and stronger and as the demand rises, so does the amount of power produced. Quite an elegant curve is produced in that area. These developments will shortly make nuclear power unnecessary.

The economics of nuclear power are already so severely in doubt that utilities in the United States of America have cancelled contracts and elected to lose tens of millions of dollars rather than proceed. Where are nuclear power plants proceeding? They are proceeding in areas where the nations wish to use the byproducts to make nasty and unpleasant atomic weapons. Democracies such as the Philippines, South Korea, Libya and Argentina have installed nuclear power plants. They want them for the plutonium which they can get from the spent fuel rods which can be so conveniently and easily made into atomic bombs. Now that the United States has rejected the suggestions of Professor Ringwood of the Australian National University for Synroc, for storing nuclear waste, as I read recently in a prominent US magazine, even that red herring can be refuted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has rejected it?

—According to a magazine article which I read quite recently, it has been rejected by the United States. I will give the honourable senator a copy. I agree that Professor Ringwood's effort was a good one. I am a little surprised that that reaction was taken. It is a fact that in spite of talk of Synroc and classification, more than 90 per cent of all the world's nuclear wastes are still in dangerous temporary storage, which must deteriorate quite soon to the extent that not one but a whole succession of dangerous accidents will occur. That must lead to higher cancer rates, malformations and spontaneous abortions, these being the things which will characterise this brave new nuclear world.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government knows that what I say is true. On what basis can it equivocate over the uranium policy? The industry is known to be dangerous and capable of causing pollution that can last for tens of thousands of years. It is known to be closely associated with the making of nuclear weapons. The old lie that plutonium from a nuclear powerhouse cannot be used for atom bombs has now been thoroughly refuted. The material will explode all right. It will destroy cities, take lives and pollute the environment massively, because such bombs are very dirty in terms of fall-out. Only the yield is not able to be reliably assessed.

The Australian Democrats take the equivocation of the Government over this matter very seriously indeed. Millions of Australians who oppose the nuclear industry voted for the Australian Labor Party on this policy. Now it seems to be betraying that policy. We will not stand idly by and see that happen. If there is an electoral disadvantage to the Government because of this, so be it. There will, of course, be an electoral disadvantage. I know that many ALP members and senators agree with me. I say to them: This issue is too big and too important for them not to follow their own conscience. They must continue to try to fight for what they know is right. On this issue I plead with them-only on this issue; I ask for this and no other-even to use their votes against the Government to see that a sane and responsible uranium policy is followed by this nation.

A firm anti-uranium policy by Australia would have a vast effect on the world. We would then be in a genuine position to see that the present hopelessly inadequate inspection and non-proliferation conditions are tightened up. That must happen as soon as possible. I appeal again to all honourable senators: If they want to be remembered by their own grandchildren and great grandchildren as men and women of principle and courage who did what they could to solve this terrible nuclear dilemma which we face, do as I suggest. Or are they content to be numbered among the lemmings, the short term opportunists and the yes men who find it more expedient to go along with what seems easiest rather than what is right?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and Senator Kilgariff who will also take part in the debate on the prevarication of the Government, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in particular, over uranium policy. Having listened to Senator Mason, my immediate reaction was that somebody probably put up a self-same emotional argument when electricity was first introduced. History books record that there was the same emotion in the community at that stage about the number of people who would be electrocuted and so forth and that we should not go ahead with that form of power. It is unfortunate that the issue of uranium mining and nuclear power do evoke that emotional response, mainly out of ignorance in the minds of many people.

SPEECH.PARA: Every time the debate comes up much is done to try to tie together the proliferation of nuclear weapons with nuclear power generation. If we want to use that argument let us put together the use of titanium in fighter aircraft as against the use of civilian aircraft. Let us put together the use of rocket fuel for intercontinental ballistic missiles as against the use of rocket fuels for putting up communication satellites and so on. Let us use the argument that aeroplanes could be used for delivering weapons and all the rest of it per se. The fact is that if a nation wants to develop a nuclear weapon it puts in a reactor. It does not have to get its uranium from us. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) rightly said, there is plenty of uranium in the sea water. Expense does not come into it when nations go down that track. They can get their uranium out of granite, sea water or wherever. Nations which use nuclear power do not use the same reactors to make plutonium for their nuclear weapons. Nuclear weapons use the pure plutonium 239. The plutonium which comes out of the power reactors is very dirty, including plutonium 239, 240, 241 and so on. It is spurious and emotional to try to go against the mining of uranium and the nuclear power industry by using the argument of nuclear weapons in the same debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have the capacity for one, you have the capacity for the other.

—Nobody is denying that. If we have the capacity to build an aircraft to deliver people we have the capacity to build an aircraft to deliver nuclear weapons. If we are worried about war let us get out and be against war. It does not matter how we kill. It is the war that is terrible. It makes no difference whether one has been shot, bayoneted or burnt up in a nuclear blast; one is dead. Let us try to get some better understanding between nations. That is what will stop the use of nuclear weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have to concentrate our thoughts in this debate on the balanced use of our energy resources. We have plenty; there is a whole myriad of them. Senator Sir John Carrick said in a debate that we must ensure that we do not isolate one potential danger and ignore other great dangers. I am not denying that there are certain dangers associated with the nuclear power cycle. The point I am making is that there are probably fewer than there are with a lot of others. We must realise that there are other dangers with other cycles and, indeed, with other industries. We worry about the waste from nuclear power. Senator Mason mentioned that. Plenty of work is going on. I have been to places where vitrification is going on. Our own Australian National University has developed the synroc process but my understanding is that there is not sufficient waste in the world to make Synroc a commercially viable operation on a large scale.

Why are we worried just about that? Occasionally there is a debate in the media or in the public mind about other wastes from industry, but not to the extent that there is debate about waste from nuclear power. Dare I mention dioxin, which is a waste product of industry? Polychlorinated biphenyl, PCB, is another waste product, as are heavy metals. One can go to the old gold mining areas where cyanide has been used in the extraction process. My colleague Senator Kilgariff is fully aware of the situation that applied in the Finniss River in the Northern Territory, which is near Rum Jungle. Radioactivity did not cause the unfortunate problems associated with the Finniss River. The heavy metals that were associated with the mining and the processing caused the problems. It had nothing to do with radioactivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is being completely rehabilitated.

—And it has been rehabilitated, as have most other mining areas, whether they be uranium or other minerals. There are plenty of problems associated with fossil fuel which some people, apparently, do not want to recognise. If we think that we can go on burning fossil fuel ad infinitum without taking into account the ultimate effects on our atmosphere and what it will do to future generations, we are not being very responsible. We are probably being more like the lemmings that Senator Mason referred to than he would like to think.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at these problems. The coal mining industry is far more dangerous than the uranium mining industry. The uranium mining industry is a basic hard-rock mining industry. There are now far fewer deaths in that industry than there were from black lung or pneumoconiosis. We have fixed that. There were far fewer deaths in the early days of the uranium mining industry because of radon gas than there were in the coal mining industry. We have now solved the problem with the adequate ventilation of the mines. The effluent that comes from coal fired power stations vis-a-vis the effluent from nuclear power stations is almost horrific. Even with the best scrubbers in the world radioactivity, sulphur dioxide, and carbon dioxide go up the funnels of coal fired power stations. We are laying an horrific future for the world unless we do something about that.

This brings me back to my idea of a balanced use of resources. Scientists are now starting to worry about carbon dioxide and the greenhouse effect and what that will do to future generations. It will cause a partial melting of some of the ice caps if it continues. We are looking at a probable doubling of the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere by about year 2025. The heat which radiates from the earth will be reflected back. Already there has been a discernible rise in the temperature of the earth over the last 20 years. We are looking at a possible rise of about three to five degrees centigrade by 2025.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that will be of some benefit, will it not? The latest thinking on the matter seems to be that this will really lead to increases in food production throughout the world.

—It could in some parts, but not in others. The melting of the ice cap will not be so good for people living on sea shores. They will have to move. People living inland will then be on the sea shore. It is predicted that some of the great food producing areas of the world will become dust bowls. There will be a massive shift. On top of that, there is a phenomenon acid rain with us now. We are fortunate in Australia. I guess that makes us a little blase about what happens in the rest of the world. Hundreds of thousands of deaths have been caused by smog in European countries. I have spoken to people living in Los Angeles who have said that rain stings their faces because of the acid in it. We are now seeing forests being denuded across the far north of North America, Canada, and the north of Europe in Sweden, Norway and Denmark. A lot of problems are being created by heavy industry in Czechoslovakia, and East Germany . Forests are dying. Lakes are dead because of the acid content and fish are dying. I am not talking of the future; it is happening now.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the point that I began with-that we have to use properly the energy that is available. Currently there is no cleaner or safer source of energy than uranium. Senator Mason rightly mentioned the use of alternatives. He mentioned wind power and solar power. How far can one go with those? We cannot deny that it is a basic fact of physics that for every square metre of ground with the sun directly overhead we get one kilowatt of power. That cannot be increased. With all that we know at this time, we can get only 10 per cent of that power anyhow. In other words, with one square metre of photovoltaic cells or a steam generating reflector-a small scale outfit-we could light one 100-watt bulb at the source. That does not allow for any transmission loss.

TALK.START.PARA: —A car has just been driven across Australia using about one square foot of solar cells.

—That is from one square metre. It is a physical fact that when the sun goes down, or one is in the northern or southern climes, there are different situations. We can use wind generation too. But what will the conservationists say when they see forests of windmills scattered all over the countryside? The one alternative solar power station that is generating on a part commercial basis and a part research and development basis is Barstow in southern California. Senator Mason and I have both been there. It is behind Los Angeles. There, 72 acres of heliostats are used to generate up to 10 megawatts of power given ideal conditions. Of course, once the sun goes down or clouds come over, that is the end. A nuclear power station could generate about 2,000 megawatts for 24 hours a day in the same situation. I am making the point of balanced use. Let us use our coal but let us use it sparingly until we see where the greenhouse effect is taking us and until we know what we can do about the acid rain. Let us use nuclear power. I am a great believer that Australia should go nuclear. It would make great sense to have a base power station about 1,000 megawatts somewhere between Adelaide and Melbourne or between Melbourne and Sydney. Such base power stations would take a lot of strain off the hydro-power stations, which could then be used for peak load. It could also take a strain off fossil fuels, which are causing smog. Those who fly a lot have noticed smog, particularly over Sydney, because of the burning of fossil fuel both in power generation and by motor vehicles. I cannot understand the people who call themselves conservationists getting so mixed up in this argument because, as I said, nuclear power generation probably causes fewer environmental and land use problems than do coal fired power stations.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Justice Fox, in his report on the Ranger project and the nuclear power industry, tabulated about 10 things which had to be looked for in respect of the coal mining industry and the generation of power from coal. I cannot understand people who say they are conservationists being so much against uranium. We really only have to look outside the front of Parliament House to see that aesthetic delight there. Those people purport to be conservationists and are very anti-uranium. I even saw a sign there stating 'uranium kills'. For heaven's sake, we can say that cars and aeroplanes kill. But our society has decided that there are acceptable risks associated with the use of motor vehicles, motor bikes and aeroplanes. But for these people, apparently there is no acceptable risk with uranium mining or uranium power generation when to this point in time they have proved to be one of the safest methods of mining and one of the safest methods of power generation.

I conclude my remarks by returning to the point raised by Senator Chaney. In all of this we have a Prime Minister who says one thing to the business community. He is almost like a Liberal Prime Minister when he speaks to the business community and around the world; he has just about out-liberaled the Liberals. However, he certainly does not say the same things in this House. He is not game. However, he said to the inaugural lunch of the Business Council of Australia:
As far as our Government is concerned, the Federal Government, and the Government of South Australia, the Roxby development is going ahead, and nothing is going to stop that.
He has never yet said that in this place. He has not been game to say it in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the claim by the Liberal and National parties in this chamber that the Senate should be discussing as a matter of public importance the prevarication of the Government, and the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) in particular, over uranium policy. It is worth while, I think, to note the structure of this matter thrust into the parliamentary program at short notice in order to divert this chamber from discussing, as was scheduled, the Medicare program of the Government. This matter has been presented today in the form of a matter of public importance rather than an urgency motion, as this self-same topic was presented some fortnight ago. That is because the Liberal and National parties opposite suffered such a humiliating defeat on bringing that motion to a vote that they have decided today to fall short of that and bring forward instead a matter of public importance on which they know a vote will not be taken and therefore their barrenness of thought, their poverty of policy, will not be exposed by a division of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Having made those very brief remarks on the actual structure of the matter, as I say, thrust into the parliamentary program this afternoon, I want to speak to the substance of the claim that the Government has prevaricated in this matter.

I took the trouble to go to the Parliamentary Library and look up the dictionary to assure myself as the meaning of the word 'prevarication' because it seemed to me, on the face of it, to have no relation to the activity of this Government. I found that in the dictionary it is defined as meaning to evade the central issues by shifting around and confusing the issues so that the question is not faced. I absolutely and utterly refute that charge being made this afternoon. What an audacious charge to bring against the Government from that side of the chamber! When one considers the parliamentary performance over seven years of the Liberal and National parties in relation to this matter, one can see prevarication personified. For seven years they failed to come to grips with the issue in a way which would allow them to come into this chamber and offer a legislative framework, a statute or a series of statutes which would control the development of this resource, if indeed it were to be developed. Year after year , and I note that Senator Mason is nodding his head in assent, there was brought into this chamber various piecemeal amendments to the Atomic Energy Act and, both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats pleaded for the Government to bring in a fully fledged, fully considered legislative framework which would perhaps hive off the research from the safeguards and entrepeneurial activities of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, just for a start. In other words, we pleaded with the Government to identify and define the functions and tasks which should be performed and to provide a proper legislative framework for them. But instead, as I say, for seven years we had piecemeal amendments to a legislative framework established in the 1950s, during a time which, as I have said before in this chamber, we supplied uranium for the nuclear weapons programs of our allies. The 1950s cold war era was the legislative framework which this Government used for seven years to guide, as it put it, the development of the uranium industry in Australia. If ever there was prevarication in this chamber in relation to coming to grips with that matter, that was it. But it is not altogether surprising because the fact is that the party organisations behind the parliamentary members of the now Opposition also utterly failed to come to grips with this problem.

If there is something that can be said about the Labor Party and the Democrats, it is that we have very publicly and painfully in our various conferences and our resolutions, which have a status which is not the same as that which applies to resolutions of the Liberal and National parties' supreme organisation, tried to identify and confront the real issues and questions which must be faced if this abundant energy source is ever to be developed. When one looks to the Liberal Party, one finds that it is bereft of policy in this area. When one looks at the Federal platform of the Liberal Party of Australia, which I obtained from the Library, under the heading 'Natural Resources' where one might hope to find some mention of uranium, there is nothing to be found. I do not know what the honourable senator opposite is holding up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I referred to that in my speech. I referred to 'Uranium- Australian Policy 1977'. We set out our policies for all of these areas in great detail in parliamentary paper No. 198 of 1977.
—Is that a party organisation paper or a parliamentary party paper?
—It is a parliamentary party paper.

—I am not referring to that. I am referring to the party organisation which lies behind the parliamentary membership. In the energy section of the Liberal Party's national platform one can find no mention of uranium. But in relation to the development of energy resources, the only criterion put forward is 'reliance to the greatest extent possible on competitive market forces, including the pricing mechanism'. If ever there was prevarication in the sense of a failure to face up to the real issues involved in the development of this resource, there it is, because the only criterion offered by the Liberal Party to guide the development of this resource is the competitive pricing mechanism. In other words, the profit motive should be the sole and certainly the guiding and dominant criterion. We say that that completely fails to come to grips with what must be dealt with if one is to be prudent in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there are matters which need to be of immediate and wider concern. Of immediate concern-to some extent it explains the cautious approach of this Government-is the fact that we could not responsibly come into government and immediately overnight cause havoc in the townships and amongst the workers who are dependent on the Ranger and Nabarlek mines. To immediately snatch away the livelihood of some 500 workers who are involved in those existing and operating mines would be scandalous. It would have been totally irresponsible, immediately and overnight to put in jeopardy the arrangements of the various Aboriginal communities which have been freely negotiated between their representatives and the mining companies. We do not intend to make an absolute, immediate judgment in those matters but to take a more deliberate, painstaking and considered course. The consequences of our action could be of a devastating kind in relation to those townships and obviously we have to be prudent in coming to our decisions in relation to those matters. However, that does not prejudge the issue. I am merely speaking of prudence and caution in the consideration of these matters.

Wider issues have to be considered and these have been touched on well, I think , by Senator Mason. The nuclear non-proliferation issues are of concern to us all, as many honourable senators have pointed out in this chamber from time to time. If we are to avoid the nuclear holocaust which could bring human history to an end, we have to find a means, as far as possible, to halt the proliferation of nuclear weapons and we must ensure that the international community in 1985 continues to give its allegiance to that United Nations Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons which in that year is due to be further discussed. This Government, unlike the previous Government, has taken the symbolic but practical step of appointing an Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, who has as one of his prime concerns the putting of the Australian Government's view that that nuclear non-proliferation treaty ought to be honoured. That includes not only urging those countries which are so anxious to obtain nuclear weapons for their arsenals of destruction for their regional disputes-one can name them: Argentina, Brazil, Israel, South Africa, India and Pakistan, some of which we know or suspect already have these weapons-not to obtain the weapons, so that proliferation can be stopped, but also reminding the superpowers which have them what is required by Article 6 of that Treaty, that is, to reduce their nuclear arsenals. If they show good faith, perhaps other nation states may join the Treaty. That is what the Australian Government is certainly urging on the international community.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you would accept that there has been a bipartisan approach here to try to urge that?

—What I am saying is that that is one of the matters which leads us to be more cautious and prudent than the Opposition apparently wants. It wants us to make immediate decisions to allow the unhindered, unfettered development of this particular energy resource. That is something we will not do because of our obligation in this instance to human history itself, to ensure that none of our nuclear products moves into the international nuclear weapons cycle.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the disposal of waste, it is once again extremely relevant to mention, as Senator Mason did, the efforts of Professor Ringwood, the director of the Research School of Earth Sciences at the Australian National University. Professor Ringwood claims to have developed a method of immobilising high level wastes for periods exceeding the aeons which are needed to guard the radioactive wastes from permeating and moving into various environments, which then of course could lead to disasters for animal and human life. The fact is that no radioactive waste has yet been incorporated in Synroc, even at the laboratory stage. I think this Government is right in allocating funds in the Budget to encourage the further stages of this program by Professor Ringwood because it is extremely important not only that scientists come to an agreement, if they can, on methods of immobilising and trapping these extremely dangerous wastes for the long periods that will be needed but also that a situation emerges in which ordinary people in the community can have confidence that that is the case. In other words, it is not something merely to be decided upon by exchanges of learned papers in scientific journals; it is something which must have the confidence of the general community. I believe we are right to encourage that but we are not confident that it has yet been achieved.

What I am pointing out is that, far from prevaricating, this Labor Government, in the short six or seven months it has been in office, has confronted the issues, as has the Australian Labor Party organisation as a whole. We have not evaded the issues; we have not walked away from them; and we have not equivocated. We have defined the issues as best we are able and we have tried to address them in a responsible way. So I assert confidently that we are doing what every thinking Australian would wish us to do, and are doing particularly what some of the young people in our nation, who are-it would not be too much to say-tormented by the prospect of the mining of uranium in Australian and the consequences that might hold for humanity, want us to do. We are doing what those young people want us to do, that is, to halt certain activities where we are absolutely confident that they ought to be halted. That is why this Government and our Prime Minister, in face-to-face conversation with French President Mitterrand, said there would be a suspension of shipment of uranium to France under contracts already negotiated because France refuses, in its arrogant French way, to cease testing of nuclear weapons in the Pacific.

When we have definite circumstances like that, we move decisively but in relation to other matters I believe that the general community and indeed this chamber would expect us to act in a responsible and cautious manner while we, having identified the issues, try to grapple and come to grips with them. For that reason, as I say, I have no hesitation in rejecting the matter of public importance raised today. The Labor Party has tried to grapple with the problems. We are using the processes even within the Party to ensure that, for example, Cabinet alone does not make a pre-emptive decision in relation to these matters. There will be full and adequate discussion within our parliamentary party, that is, the elected representatives of the Australian people, to whom the Australian people have entrusted government. In relation to these matters, then, I say that far from prevaricating this Government has been prudent in the best sense. It has taken a cautious, practical and wise approach to these issues and for that reason, amongst others, the chamber ought to reject this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of this matter of public importance are:

SPEECH.PARA: The prevarication of the Government, and the Prime Minister in particular, over uranium policy.

The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) said that this was a tiresome rerun and that the Government was not prevaricating. The fault with that statement is that Senator Walsh did not address himself to the remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) recently, in various places, because the two sets of comments contain a mass of contradictions. Senator Tate mentioned that shipments of uranium to France had been cancelled until, I think, October 1984. He would know full well that, as France is a member of the European Economic Community, under an arrangement between member countries it can be supplied with whatever mineral or other requirements it has. So the action that was taken, though perhaps in good faith, was completely meaningless.

During the debate Senator Walsh made three allegations. First of all, he said that in theory if the Ranger project were to expand it could satisfy world demand for Australian uranium. Perhaps that is superficially true. The fact is that Senator Walsh should know that both the Germans and the Japanese are the principal importers of Ranger uranium and while they want to curtail their imports of Ranger uranium this is because they want to diversify supplies of the concentrate from other sources. Of course we see on the world market these days that, among other reasons, this is why Nigor and Kabor and other places in South Africa have become suppliers. The purchasers of uranium throughout the world for various reasons wish to diversify.

Secondly, Senator Walsh claimed that world prices for uranium were depressed. Is this really true? The reality of the situation is that prices for uranium have risen from some $17 a pound to $24 a pound and are still on an upward curve . At any rate, we are concerned with the situation in 1988 prices in new developments, not 1983 prices. Further, Senator Walsh claimed that the previous Government did not approve a contract for the sale of uranium to the Central Electricity Generating Board in England because of the low prices for uranium negotiated. Of course this comment is quite mischievous. The truth is that the previous Government, through Doug Anthony, did not approve the variation in market price arrangements under which there was to be a high price in the earlier stages of the contracts but which would then be reduced. It was not a case of prices becoming too low. He disagreed with the contractual arrangements.

Since March, the Labor Government has been agonising, trying to resolve its policy. It is quite obvious, when one sees the State of the Australian Labor Party with its left wing, its moderates and such, that the Government is in a state of confusion. This would have to be because of the present lack of leadership from Mr Hawke. Let us look at this confusion. On 2 September, Mr Hawke said, at a business lunch-it has been repeated before-that there was unequivocal commitment to Roxby Downs going ahead. He added:
As far as our Government is concerned . . . that Roxby development is going ahead and nothing is going to stop that . . .

Was he referring to the left wing? Anyway, one would think that that would be pretty definite and that, as he was the Prime Minister speaking on behalf of the Government, Cabinet must have decided. This was on 2 September. Then Senator Walsh told Estimates Committee C that, in respect of uranium, the final policy decisions have not been made. Is Senator Walsh now telling us that Roxby Downs is not a policy decision, that it is his own decision, or that no decision has been taken at all? Or is the Prime Minister shooting recklessly from the hip? Perhaps this is the case in view of the controversy now raging within the Labor Party. To compound the confusion, we were told yesterday of a Victorian ALP meeting on the weekend which decided unanimously to oppose new export contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that include Senator Button?

—We would have to look into that. Who should be a participant, but another Hawke Minister, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis)? Is he then representing government policy? Perhaps, as Minister for Industrial Relations, he thinks that he can conciliate in the dispute between the Prime Minister and the Minister for Resources and Energy. What are we left with? We are left with a clear perception of chaos and confusion, with the Minister for Resources and Energy publicly disagreeing with the Prime Minister, with the socialist left in a much more neurotic state, and with the Prime Minister giving no leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: In all this time great damage is being done to the market for Australian uranium and to the industry. As a result, jobs are being lost to a tremendous extent. One has only to look at the position in the Northern Territory to see an example of the job loss that is being experienced. There is no development. Increased employment, which would have been a tremendous fillip to the development of the north, has not taken place. Investment has been discouraged, as is quite obvious. Investors in Australia and from overseas, the people who are interested in seeing that uranium is developed for energy, must be discouraged when they see the Leader of the Australian Government, the Australian Government itself and the Ministers within that Government all making different statements, thus bringing about an utterly chaotic situation. Of course, we see growth retarded.

It is amazing that we should see a situation in which the Government, which is looking for growth and employment, is bringing about unemployment and retarding growth. Worse still, the reliability of Australia is now put under a cloud. Previously, Australia was looked upon as a country in which it was safe to invest. In view of the chaotic situation arising from the fact that we do not have a uranium policy, our main purchasers of other commodities such as America and Japan must view our reliability as being under a cloud. Of course, the extent of the damage being caused is hard to assess. It can be illustrated by two things, namely the uranium industry within the Northern Territory and projections of world markets, and unemployment.

The Koongarra and Jabiluka mines in the Northern Territory would employ up to 4 ,000 people. Total unemployment in the Northern Territory amounts to 5,900 people. I am not suggesting that development of uranium in the Northern Territory would overcome the full extent of unemployment. It would create 4,000 jobs. The development of the Northern Territory can be measured in terms of the many young people in Australia who would go there looking for opportunities. In the construction phase of about three years about 1,500 people would be employed . The expected life of Jabiluka is 25 years and that of Koongarra 12 years. Over the next four years, if the developments were to go ahead, $630m would be invested in Jabiluka and $150m in Koongarra. Already some $55m has been spent at Jabiluka and $100m at Koongarra. For both mines that is an investment in 1984 of $275m, in 1985 of $275m and in 1986 of $260m. In addition, $50m will be invested in the final construction year. The revenue to Australia from these two mines would be enormous. In 1986 we would be looking at $155m; in 1987, $385m; and in 1990, $810m. Even by the year 2000 it is projected that there would be $655m in revenue in 1982 dollars. The Northern Territory, which requires immense amounts of money for development, would get 18 per cent of this revenue.

The Aboriginals would also benefit from royalties and payments. They certainly realise this now because they, the traditional owners, are still waiting for the Federal Government to give them the answer to their message stick that they wish to go ahead and develop uranium for the benefit of their people. At Jabiluka, for instance, $1.5m has already been paid to Aboriginals; $10m is payable when production starts; and 4.5 per cent will be paid in special royalties. At Koongarra during the first 10 years of production $20m pre-tax is paid per year to Aboriginals and an all-up figure in equity and royalties. In gross terms the failure to go ahead with these two mines will cost Australia in loss of construction expenditure and production $10,000m for the life of the mines. Can Australia afford that? Can Australia afford to have the policies of the present Government? This is what is being put at risk by the Prime Minister's failure to give leadership and his failure to decide to proceed.

I turn now to the matter of world demand. At present there are some 294 nuclear reactors. There are 215 more in various areas of production. By 1985 France will have 55 per cent of electricity generated from nuclear fuel. By 1988 the United States will be a net importer of nuclear fuel. Australia, if it could become a politically stable and democratic country-it is at least democratic, but it is unstable at present-could have a very attractive future having in mind the importers of the future. Therefore it is high time that with all this potential to create wealth for Australia, to develop our resources, to create jobs and to give government the revenue it is crying for, to help the Aboriginal people-they certainly need help and are 100 per cent behind the mining of uranium-the Government made its decision to give Australia the fillip it requires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on this matter of public importance I want to respond to some of the rather wild statements that have been made by Opposition senators who apparently do not as yet appreciate that they are in opposition because they had no policies on specific and general main areas. The people rejected them in March and will continue to reject them until they can come up with positive policies. One of the policies that we put forward at that time was that there had to be adequate safeguards before we could permit the uranium industry to go ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just touch on one of the matters Senator Collard raised when he talked about the waste problem and suggested that we should be concerning ourselves more with other industries. I am glad to see that he has not left the chamber. By way of interjection I then raised the matter of the coal industry. I make the point once again that it was entirely the failure of the coal industry to make adequate provisions for health and safety measures in that industry that caused so many deaths. If Senator Collard cared to speak to his friends and associates in that industry he might ensure that those coal mines that are still operating are operating in such a manner that will reduce the death toll from those horrific diseases. We had similar problems in the asbestos industry with mesothelioma and asbestosis because of the failure, once again of industry, to provide proper health and safety safeguards. We are seeing the same matters raised in the uranium industry. It was interesting that Senator Kilgariff elected to speak on the matter of employment, because on the figures I have before me, in a document which is entitled 'Economics of Australian Uranium Mining-Economic Factors related to Australian Uranium Mining and Export' it states that at the moment:

There are . . . approximately 2,180 people directly employed in the uranium industry. Many of these people are employed in construction jobs and will no longer be so when that phase of operation is over. By 1984 employment will probably be between 1,430 and 1,530 . . . The Ranger Inquiry Report contained estimates that in direct employment in townships due to uranium mining was around 25 per cent. Therefore, total uranium mining township employment would be around 2,000 in 1984.

The multiplier effect on employment generated elsewhere is harder to estimate. However, using general resources boom estimates, the Australian economist, Johns , has arrived at the figure of 4,000 additional indirect jobs.

We have heard of this mythical figure of 500,000 jobs to be created with the development of the Australian uranium industry. I recall that that was the headline splashed all over the daily newspapers when the previous Government-I stress the word 'previous'-was in operation. It was claimed that 500,000 jobs would be created in the uranium industry with the go-ahead of the Liberal- National Party coalition. Those 500,000 jobs did not eventuate. They will not because there has never been a proven estimate that 500,000 jobs could become available.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was plucked from the air.

—It was a figure plucked from the air. It was one of those figures that somebody dreamed up or had a nightmare about. The previous Government was not terribly sure how it could sell uranium mining. It thought that it could sell it to the Australian people on the basis that it would provide employment. That has not eventuated, and it will not because there are not that many jobs available no matter how hard one pushes the industry.
—Have you been to Jabiru?

—There is not going to be that degree of employment opportunities available, no matter what one does. I agree with that portion of the matter of public importance which states that we are prevaricating. Yes, we are indeed prevaricating on the uranium policy issue, and we are prevaricating for very good reasons, not the least of which is the instability of the industry at the moment. The Opposition is constantly quoting and misquoting Australian Labor Party policy. I make it quite clear right now, as I have at all times, that the part of the policy that concerns me most is that which applies to adequate safeguards for waste disposal.

SPEECH.PARA: In any debate on uranium many other considerations have to be taken into account. Only days ago there was a newspaper report concerning the latest nuclear power station to be opened in Great Britain. It opened one day and closed five days later after a steam leak. The interesting part of that news item concerns the absolute incredible escalation of costs. They went from a projected $A425m to a completion figure of $A1,156m. That is the potential cost. The Central Electricity Generating Board said at that time:
'We will have to operate at full power for 30 years before we get to a break even stage'.

And that is supposed to be an economical industry. The consumers got a bit of a shock too because they suddenly found that their rates were dramatically increased and they did not like it very much at all. At the moment France is considering introducing other measures because of oversupply. It is talking about manipulation of the uranium market. Russia is revising its nuclear power program because it is concerned about the safety, or lack of safety, in the nuclear power industry.

I come back once again-because of the limit of time on matters of public importance-to the problems of waste disposal. Look at the situation that has developed quite recently with Professor Ringwood and Synroc, which I understand some members of the Opposition were promoting prior to the last election. In fact one suggested we might like to have a nuclear power station on, I think, King Island and that because we had the Synroc program so well advanced we would be able to take care of any waste disposal problem. Synroc is not advanced to that stage. It is barely past a laboratory experiment. Questions regarding Synroc are being raised. We have the problem of the storage of waste until such time as it can be put into Synroc. We have the problem of the cooling ponds. For instance, what does one do with millions of gallons of radioactive waste which has to be dried out before it can be converted and introduced to Synroc? Where do we put these cooling ponds? Do we have them scattered in everybody's back yard?

TALK.START.PARA: —In Lang Hancock's back yard.

—Lang Hancock, the mining magnate from the west, did at one time state he would not mind having a nuclear power station in his back yard. His neighbours objected to it quite strongly and I am sure they would consider doing the same if he put a radioactive waste cooling pond in his back yard. There are areas of further research.
—Or a coal stockpile.

—I have had my say about coal, as the honourable senator has on a number of occasions. A little earlier I answered his accusations about the number of deaths in the coal industry. Perhaps he was not listening, so I will go over it again. I said then that it was entirely because of the failure of the coal industry to provide adequate health and safety standards that there were so many deaths in the industry. I said also that it was the failure of the asbestos industry to provide those adequate health and safety standards that caused and is causing so many deaths in that industry. If honourable senators want to know about the uranium industry, I have a very interesting book in my office. I have read it into Hansard or by leave incorporated it in Hansard. It lists every accident that has been reported in the nuclear power industry. It is an impressive list.
—A thick volume.

—It is a very thick, sick volume. It is an extremely concerning document, but no more concerning than the statements that are being made here and in other places about what Synroc is going to do. I would welcome the news that Synroc is the answer to the waste disposal problem. It has not been proven to be that as yet, and until such time as it is, I am not prepared to accept it. We have seen over the years a number of supposedly safe methods of disposal of radioactive waste. All of them have been proved to be irresponsible in that they have not been adequate, they have not been safe. There is no such thing as a comprehensive and adequate safe disposal method for radioactive waste at this time. Until such time as there is, the Labor Party and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will continue to prevaricate in the uranium industry because we have a commitment-
—To prevaricate.

—To prevaricate in the true sense of the word, means to delay. The honourable senator should look up his dictionary. We are delaying for very good reason. If honourable senators opposite want me to take the last four minutes of my time talking about the other problems of the proliferation of nuclear weapons I am happy to do so. But I will content myself with saying that I am quite happy for the Prime Minister and the Labor Government to prevaricate in the uranium industry until such time as it is assured that the well-being and the welfare of the Australian people and the people of the world, which are paramount to a Labor government, are being upheld. I suggest that we have spent quite enough time on this mischievous matter of public importance introduced by the Opposition, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the business of the day be called on.

I speak very briefly on the annual report of the Australian Science and Technology Council, known colloquially as ASTEC. Amongst other things, I think it is important occasionally for senators and other parliamentarians to commend the work of the very fine Australians who give of their time and resources of mind and intellect to aid the Government in coming to rational and reasonable decisions in relation to the matters on which they have some special expertise. Certainly, ASTEC is made up of many Australians of quite diverse and distinguished backgrounds in public affairs, from academies of learning and private enterprise who have contributed to governments forming much better policies than would otherwise have been the case in relation to science and technology in Australia. As I have said, perhaps we do not often enough commend the work of such people and I believe that we should take this opportunity to do so.

Some idea of the scope of the work of ASTEC can be gleaned from the fact that it meets more or less on a monthly basis and that it produced, as listed in appendix G, some nine reports which were tabled or presented to the Prime Minister over the period under review. Of course, it is to the Prime Minister that ASTEC reports. That is as it ought to be. It is, of course, in accordance with the practice in other countries that such groups should report direct to the head of government rather than to a particular Minister. It is important that, should any conflicts of interest arise between Ministries in relation to matters of significant national importance, rather than the Minister with operational responsibility for the area having all the information, the head of government-in our case the Prime Minister-ought to have this information available so that a considered and good decision can be arrived at.

The key to the future activity of ASTEC-I am pleased to note this-probably lies in the remarks contained in the introduction on page 2 of the report and I will paraphrase those remarks somewhat. If Australia is to compete in an international environment increasingly dominated by skill and technology, rather than resource advantages, ASTEC itself must broaden the scope of those issues to which it addresses itself in order to contribute to government formulation of policy. One has in mind the fact that Australian governments have increasingly placed emphasis on the contribution which science and technology can rightly make to our economic recovery through improving the competitiveness of existing industries and the development of new ones.

Of course, not only must one have a sound industry policy, such as that developed by Senator John Button and Mr Barry Jones, but also one must have the underpinning of a sound national education policy and a generally sympathetic national government which can provide an environment in which the skill based industries, the brain based industries can flourish. To that extent I was delighted to see during the past week the Government announce the implementation of its response to the report of the Espie High Technology Financing Committee which, of course, links the tremendous scientific ferment and activity that takes place in Australia-our contribution to pure science is quite remarkable and significant as Senator Robertson also quite rightly emphasises-with the entrepreneurial, industrial and commercial front. Of course, with the unveiling last week of the Government's tax incentives for so-called sunrise industries, we see a pledge by this Government and its Treasury, which will forgo some $20m of revenue in order to stimulate some $40m worth of investment in sunrise industries, that we are interested in fostering this new industry which will not only give employment opportunities to many Australians but also generate wealth which can be distributed throughout the community.

I commend Senator Button and Mr Jones for their work in ensuring that Australia will have a type of business structure which can encourage the development of biotechnology, genetic engineering, personal computers, the writing of computer programs, medical technologies, communications equipment, solar energy cells and all those other matters which lie at the forefront, one hopes, of that supplementing of our traditional ways of generating wealth in our community. I conclude by saying once again that I believe congratulations are due to the members of ASTEC for the help and aid which they have given to the Government. I hope that the Government will continue to pay significant attention to the reports of that body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion in respect of the annual report of the Australian Science and Technology Council I echo the sentiments expressed by Senator Tate when he paid tribute to the time voluntarily given by, and the effort and the expertise of those who make up ASTEC. Of course, in doing so, that does not mean that anyone on either side of the chamber is absolutely bound to the acceptance of every word in the reports of ASTEC as if they were holy writ. In fact, there are some aspects of some of the reports with which I am sure some of us would disagree. But one aspect of the work of ASTEC which I think is worth commenting on is the problem of communication between the technologist, the scientist, the economist and the rest of the world-those who have to make and implement decisions which involve technology and science.
—You are getting with it, Senator. This is good.

—If the honourable senator will just listen he will get a good idea of what I am going to put forward. I was very impressed some years ago with a discussion I had with Professor Bradbury of Stirling University where he had developed what I think was probably the first entirely new course in the world of what he called technological economics. This new discipline was intended to develop people who had a training in the art and perhaps even the science of communication between those who were the technologists and the scientists and those who were the businessmen and economists so that the twain can meet. I believe that one of the biggest problems we have is the lack of understanding and empathy-I am not suggesting there is antipathy-which exists between the various disciplines and various trainings in conceptual thinking. I would, as I have done for a number of years, urge again that further consideration be given to running an appropriate course at a suitable university so that we can perhaps include on ASTEC some people with a specific training in the discipline of technological economics.

SPEECH.PARA: I was somewhat disappointed, when having raised this matter as I have on a number of occasions with the Council of the Australian National University, I found it was referred to the economics department which said that it had looked at transport economics and one or two other things but it did not think technological economics would advance the situation very much at all.

In other words, they missed entirely the point of what on earth it was supposed to be about. It is the development of an entirely new discipline, of a communicator between the various disciplines. It is not to train economists and it is not to train technologists. It is to be able to bring somebody in between who can create a communication between them. As I have said previously on a number of occasions, I hope that ASTEC's performance will in the not too distant future be enhanced by the addition of some people with this type of training. I again refer to Professor Bradbury's course at Stirling University as a good base for that.

I wish to use the occasion of the tabling of this report to make an appeal to the economic rationalism of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh ). When we were on the Government benches, we heard many lectures from him about rational economic approaches to Australia's various problems. The Petroleum Products Pricing Authority and its interaction with State price controls on petrol present an opportunity for the Minister for Resources and Energy to bring his talents to bear in the community interest. In the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority we have a body which was established by the previous Government to take over the role which previously had been carried out by the Prices Justification Tribunal with respect to the pricing of petroleum products. The Fraser Government accepted a price surveillance and pricing authority role in the public interest. That may be a good proposition but I suppose that some would say that even that interference with the market is unlikely to be productive for consumers in the long term.

The real difficulty that I wish to draw to Senator Walsh's attention-a difficulty of which I am sure he is aware-is the fact that, alongside the Commonwealth Petroleum Products Pricing Authority, is a series of State authorities which exercise a price fixing role in this area. Indeed, it is a particularly prized policy of a number of governments, including the New South Wales and Western Australian governments. We therefore have the extraordinary position of those in the industry being subject to two sets of price controls. Certainly, they appear to be unanimous in their view that this is inefficient and that very often the operation of the State mechanisms is such that they are denied a fair return for their capital and a fair return for their efforts and labours.

I understand that from the consumer's point of view the price of fuel is a sensitive matter. I understand further that, given the very competitive state of the industry at the moment because of the drop in demand, and as a result of that drop in demand the fact that companies are tending to compete very heavily with each other from time to time to retain market share, the actual prices set by State authorities at times do seem to be irrelevant. Over the last couple of years difficulties and inefficiencies in the system of dual controls have emerged. I do not believe that that sort of efficiency is in the interests of consumers or indeed in the interests of the community generally. I ask Senator Walsh-I acknowledge that I did not mention to him that I wished to speak on this report; the fact that he is not in the chamber is very reasonable in those circumstances, but I am sure his staff will draw his attention to the fact that I am raising it now-to direct his attention to this difficulty, which is a real one. In speaking briefly to the review of ANZUS, I welcome Mr Hayden's statement which reaffirms the commitment to ANZUS despite the left wing of the Australian Labor Party which was obviously out to ensure that the ANZUS agreement was dispensed with. I am also pleased to see the rejection of the non-aligned policy which would have left Australia defenceless. Indeed, there would have been no cohesion in defence in that part of the world. I am also pleased to note the recognition given by the Government to the shared interests and the values and history of the ANZUS partners, the United States of America, New Zealand and Australia. Of course, at one stage much interest was taken in the media regarding the future of ANZUS. I am pleased to see the situation that has arisen through the actions of Mr Hayden.

Two aspects of the agreement affect the Northern Territory, from which I am one of the senators. They relate to the greater defence preparedness and the greater capabilities in that area and Pine Gap. With regard to defence preparedness, in his speech Mr Hayden said that Australia's prime defence role was to build up self defence capability within our regional context. Of course, this is a very reasonable attitude to take, particularly now that Australia must be self- contained as much as possible within its defence capability. In the north, there has to be further upgrading of defence facilities. In the last few years considerable action has been taken in the setting up of patrol boat bases in Darwin and various other communications and defence measures, all of which help the potential for Australia to look after itself.

In the future we should look to see the Royal Australian Air Force base at Tindal developed further. As honourable senators will know, within the last few months No. 75 Squadron has returned from Malaysia to Australia and is now based in Darwin. I hope that finance will be made available by the Government soon to ensure that the base at Tindal will be improved. This, of course, will be to the benefit of No. 75 squadron in the next few years when the Mirage squadron is replaced by the FA18 squadron. Stage 2 of Jindalee over-the-horizon radar will play a major part in Australia's defence. I look forward to that being adequately financed as well. Pine Gap is one of the joint defence facilities about which Mr Hayden said:

. . . the facilities clearly represent an important reflection and instance of the shared interests which the Treaty embodies, and the government regards this form of co-operation with the United States as of unique value.

Once again, I think the Government has taken a very important step. I congratulate the Government. It shows that the Government recognises that the Pine Gap base is of considerable importance. As some honourable senators will be aware, a demonstration is to be held at Pine Gap on 11 November. It has been indicated in the Centralian Advocate in Alice Springs that Labor women senators will be participating. I believe that this is an attempt to undermine Australia' s relations with the United States. I hope that this report is incorrect. I look forward to those honourable senators indicating that that report is incorrect. All this type of demonstration does is to serve Soviet interests. It is important to remember that Pine Gap is very much a joint facility. It is administered by the Department of Defence. Commonwealth police are stationed there. All in all, it is a joint defence operation. It gives employment to many hundreds of Alice Springs people. I look forward to government action in relation to the bases I have mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome this review of ANZUS which goes a long way towards demystifying this 31-year-old treaty arrangement and, by demystifying it, placing it in a reasonable context within Australia's security situation. The review indeed follows a series of statements from prominent Americans in recent years which have warned us that ANZUS is not a protective canopy which, in each and every situation, can protect Australia from attack in time of war. ANZUS is certainly not that. All reasonable Australians who have studied the Treaty and its origins with any care , therefore would agree with the words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I do not say that the Treaty guarantees Australia's national safety and welfare, nor do I place us in that posture of happy dependence that has satisfied the foreign policy ambitions of many Australians in the past both within and without this Parliament . . . we recognise that we must still pull our full weight in our own protection.

The Democrats agree with those words. ANZUS came about in 1952 as part of the peace treaty with Japan. With the agony of the Pacific war still fresh in everybody's mind, its aim at that stage was to guard against another such war. The situation regarding Japan is now, of course, vastly different. We are friendly nations with considerable economic dependence on each other. The significance of ANZUS is diminished, to some extent, for that reason but also, more importantly, by the facts of modern war. In war, could any pact like ANZUS stop missiles arriving here? The answer is, of course, no. Two nuclear submarines carry enough missiles to destroy every Australian city and military installation of any size, with no hope at all of stopping any of them. As I said , this is freely conceded by the United States which has warned us several times against too great an expectation from ANZUS. The review, of course, recognises the basic community of interest between the United States and Australia. The Minister's statement, which appears at page 899 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 15 September 1983, makes this important proviso:
The Treaty provisions do not derogate from Australia's right of national decisions in foreign and defence policy matters.

I think it is a very important point that Australia has asserted its right to make its own decisions. Indeed, that is just as well because there is a clear message in all of this which I think the Government might well have heard. We have a major obligation to undertake our own defence and not to continue with the illusion that such self-defence is not necessary because ANZUS will do it all.

There are other means at hand, of course, in the modern world for us to defend ourselves in all circumstances short of major nuclear war. Hence, the Falklands war showed that deterrent and defensive weaponry has made vast advances compared with aggressive weaponry which tends now to be increasingly expensive and less and less reliable as time goes on. Missile armed warships, even small ones, are now fast, flexible and inexpensive. They pack an enormous punch and carry, indeed, missiles which they can deliver with the same force and ability as much larger ships. Of course, those ships have their air and military equivalents.

I used the words 'short of nuclear war'. What about nuclear war? Does the new, relaxed, demystified ANZUS, negotiated with the Americans by this Government, imply that, because ANZUS cannot defend us against nuclear war, it is still reasonable that we are called on to assume obligations to the United States that would make us a nuclear target? I refer, of course, to the North West Cape and Pine Gap bases in particular. In other words, we are expected to cop a nuclear attack in the interests of common defence in a situation where, short of spending billions and billions of dollars on anti-missile missiles which this country could never afford, all of those missiles could reach us easily and quickly.

The statement is conspicuously silent on this matter. I ask the Government to give it some thought. It will soon be a matter of debate and vote by the Democrats. It also should be amongst the people of Australia. Certainly it is no longer a situation which should just be allowed to drift on without careful examination. Perhaps such an examination would confirm that the threat posed to us by the bases is worth while. On the other hand, it might not. This is a matter for the people of Australia to consider very carefully and soon because it is possible that our very survival as a nation might be involved in it one way or another.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

When introducing the Income Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy) Bill 1983, I outlined the basic features of the Government's scheme for introduction of a Medicare levy. This Bill-the Medicare Levy Bill 1983-declares the basic rate of levy. For 1983-84 the basic rate will be 0.416 per cent of taxable income, that is, five-twelfths of the full year rate of 1 per cent. The Bill also contains rules for fixing the maximum amount of levy payable and the income points below which people with low incomes will not be called on to pay any levy.

As I mentioned in my speech on the first Bill, the basic rate will be reduced by one half for certain repatriation beneficiaries and service personnel who are liable for the levy because their dependants are eligible for Medicare benefits. Explanations of each clause of the Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum and I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

We do not wish Medibank Private to obtain a monopoly position in the private insurance market as this would sacrifice many of the cost advantages I have just outlined. For this reason we have been willing to place limitations on Medibank Private's membership so that its share of the private insurance market is restricted. The window into the private insurance market-place that Medibank Private will provide is also essential to our policy of reduced controls over the private funds' operations. We believe that private insurance can be much more effectively regulated by the use of Medibank Private as the 'honest broker' in the market.

The other major argument in favour of having a single public fund operate Medicare is the timely and accurate supply of data on doctors' services in the detection of fraud and overservicing. The continuation of the present system whereby 63 different organisations supply that data means that the accumulation of doctors' profiles is dependent on the speed of the slowest fund. The Health Insurance Commission is currently the timeliest and most accurate fund in Australia, with a 99.97 per cent accuracy level in the statistical data it supplies to the Health Department for fraud and overservicing purposes. While the overall responsibility for investigating fraud and overservicing will remain with the Health Department it is pertinent to note that the Health Insurance Commission has been among the most active of the private funds in pursuing suspected cases of fraud. In fact, the amendments to the Health Insurance Act contained in clause 58 of this Bill which make bribery by a proprietor of a private hospital an offence largely came about through the efforts of Medibank Private in pursuing what it correctly considered to be a rip-off of contributors ' funds, but which the inadequacy of the current laws prevented it taking to court.

The final factor in favour of having the HIC administer Medicare was that, as I outlined earlier, the Government would find it impossible to entrust such an important program to the private funds, considering their opposition to Labor's health policies throughout the past decade. While there would be a relationship of trust if the Health Department were to operate Medicare, it would have neither the experience to administer such a large benefit payments organisation nor the administrative efficiency that accrued to the HIC through its five years of operation in the private market.

In seeking consensus with the private funds on the introduction of the Medicare program the Government has offered a range of concessions. There are three main reasons for the concessions announced: Firstly, to guarantee a continuing substantial role for the private funds and ensure Medibank private could not gain unfair commercial advantage through the Health Insurance Commission's operation of Medicare; Secondly, to minimise the possibility of redundancies caused by Medicare's introduction; and Thirdly, because Medicare will provide basic cover to all Australians there is no longer a need for the Government to regulate the funds' operations so closely. Clause 73 of the Bill gives the Minister a general power of direction from the Health Insurance Commission. All directions made by the Minister must be set out in the annual report which is subsequently tabled in the Parliament.

Once the Parliament has agreed to this power of direction I will be making three directions in relation to Medibank Private's operations. Firstly, Medibank Private membership will be limited in each State and on each table to the numbers as at 30 June 1983. Secondly, Medibank Private operations will be limited to their present 195 offices. The greater overall work volumes following Medicare's introduction may mean some transfers to larger premises at an equivalent site. However, Medibank Private will not be able to operate from the 86 new Medicare offices which will be opened before 1 February 1984. Thirdly, to ensure that the Health Insurance Commission's operation of Medicare and Medibank Private does not give Medibank Private an unfair advantage in lower administrative costs that could be passed on in lower contribution rates, I will be directing that the management component of all their contribution rates must reflect average industry costs. These directions under section 8J of the Health Insurance Act will apply up to 30 June 1986, at which time these policies will be reviewed.
