The purpose of this Bill is to enact Commonwealth legislation to provide for the Commonwealth to undertake domestic meat inspection in New South Wales and any other State which subsequently refers the power of inspection of meat to the Commonwealth. Following negotiations between the Commonwealth and New South Wales for the transfer of the New South Wales domestic meat inspection service to the Commonwealth, thus providing for the Commonwealth to undertake all meat inspection in that State, the New South Wales Parliament passed legislation entitled the Commonwealth Powers (Meat Inspection) Act, 1983 which came into effect on 1 July 1983. It provided that the matter of the inspection of meat that is intended for human consumption or for use as animal food, to the extent to which it is not otherwise included in the legislative powers of the Parliament of the Commonwealth, is referred to the Parliament of the Commonwealth.

This Bill will apply to New South Wales and to such other States as may make the same reference of power to the Commonwealth. The Bill will also be proclaimed to apply to a Territory where this is appropriate. Thus the new legislation will provide a mechanism whereby a single, national meat inspection service operating under one Commonwealth law can be achieved with the agreement of the Governments concerned. Also on 1 July 1983 an arrangement between the Commonwealth and New South Wales came into effect which provided that the meat inspection function carried out by State officers should be carried out by the Commonwealth. From that date the State officers concerned became Commonwealth officers under the Public Service Act 1922. This arrangement was entered into by the Commonwealth pursuant to the Meat Inspection Arrangements Act 1964.

Since 1964 when that Act came into effect the dual system of meat inspection in Australia whereby the Commonwealth is responsible for inspection of product destined for export and the States are responsible for inspection of product intended for domestic consumption has been recognised by successive Commonwealth Governments as having serious disadvantages. It hinders the introduction of common standards, results in some duplication of inspection services, creates anomalies in charging levels where export meat is diverted to the local market and has led to industrial disputation due to demarcation problems. Under the 1964 Act various arrangements were entered into with South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania whereby Commonwealth meat inspectors undertook some inspection of meat intended for domestic consumption on behalf of the States concerned. These arrangements are not as all embracing as the arrangement recently entered into between the Commonwealth and New South Wales as some local government authorities and State public health authorities continue to provide inspection services to local standards at some non-export premises in those States. The existing arrangements with other States will continue until such time as each refers its powers of domestic meat inspection to the Commonwealth.

It should be noted that following the transfer of the domestic meat inspection function in New South Wales to the Commonwealth on 1 July 1983 the New South Wales Meat Industry Authority remains responsible for licensing of and construction and facilities standards in non-export abattoirs, slaughter-houses, meat processing plants and knackeries and pet food processing plants in that State. Because New South Wales retains the function of licensing slaughtering and processing premises the Bill provides that State laws which are capable of operating concurrently with the new Act can co-exist with and have effect alongside the Commonwealth law. This Government is convinced that a single national meat inspection service is necessary for meat inspection in Australia to be carried out in an efficient and cost effective manner. In this connection, I am pleased to be able to report that recently the Premier of Victoria wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) proposing that a working party consisting of Commonwealth and Victoria officials should be formed to advise both governments on arrangements necessary for the establishment of a single meat inspection service.

Meat inspection services on a national basis will only be delivered in the most efficient manner when standards for slaughtering and processing which apply to export and domestic production and in various States and Territories are, so far as is possible, common standards. An important element of the integrated national inspection service proposal is commonality of standards. The Government recognises that the existing standards which apply in slaughtering and non- slaughtering establishments in the States and Territories vary quite considerably. This Bill will allow the progressive introduction of common standards in States and Territories to which the Act is applied when the States and Territories agree to such action.

In New South Wales and South Australia all meat inspectors engaged in inspection of product for the domestic market are now officers of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry and as at 1 July 1983, about 80 per cent of full time meat inspectors in Australia were employed by the Commonwealth . Management objectives such as uniformity of conditions of employment of meat inspectors in Australia, avoidance of demarcation disputes, common training and the improved flexibility and mobility of staff are increasingly being achieved. This Bill will enable other objectives to be achieved. This Bill follows the Export Control Act 1982 and where possible the form and substance of the Bill, and particularly of parts IV, V and VI, is in the same or very similar terms to the equivalent provisions in that Act.

The Bill provides that an offence will have been committed if in the course of trade or commerce meat, which is not fit for human or animal consumption but which is intended to be used as human or animal food respectively, is transported out of or into a State or Territory to which the legislation applies . Provisions in the relevant New South Wales Act which will remain in force after this Bill comes into effect require that meat brought into that State must be taken from the carcase of an animal slaughtered at premises outside the State which have been approved by the New South Wales Meat Industry Authority. Similar provision exists in other State legislation. In order to complement such provisions which would continue to apply the Bill will provide that meat of certain kinds brought into a State or Territory to which the Act extends must be taken to prescribed premises so that it may be inspected by an authorised officer.

While inspection powers under the Bill are to be exercised by officers of the Department of Primary Industry the Bill also provides for the Secretary to that Department to appoint other persons such as officers of other Commonwealth Departments or statutory authorities or State or Territory Departments or statutory authorities to carry out the functions of authorised officers. Powers are included in the Bill, similar to those included in the Export Control Act 1982, which are necessary to facilitate enforcement of the conditions and restrictions which will be imposed. These include powers of entry and search, power to stop and detain any ship, vehicle or aircraft, and to seize meat or another matter or thing in respect of which an offence against the Act is reasonably believed to have been committed.

As with the Export Control Act 1982 these powers are accompanied by safeguards to prevent abuse. Entry into premises other than abattoirs, knackeries, meat processing plants or animal food processing plants can only take place with the consent of the occupier of the premises or in pursuance of a warrant issued by a Justice of the Peace who must be convinced of the need for entry. A time limit is to be placed on the currency of warrants. Powers of search of vehicles, ships or aircraft cannot take place unless the authorised officers produce identity cards issued to them under the Act. Similarly persons are not required to assist an authorised officer in the performance of his or her duties upon request unless such a card is produced. A limit on the time a seized matter or thing can be held unless proceedings are instituted is imposed. It will be an offence to apply a false trade description to meat that has been inspected under the Act or to interfere with or forge official marks under the Act. Such a provision will protect the application of objective carcase classifications to meat consumed in Australia in the same way that the Export Control Act 1982 applies to meat for export.

Detailed effect will be given to the provisions of the Bill by means of regulations and orders made under the regulations which will give scope for the variations which are required between particular States and Territories and for changing requirements and conditions. The penalties which the Bill provides for the commission of offences are, in respect of provisions in the same terms as provisions in the Export Control Act 1982, in the main the same as in that Act and the penalties in relation to other provisions are the same as those which apply in New South Wales under similar provisions of the State law which will be superseded by the new Commonwealth Act. After many years of discussion at all levels of industry and government this Bill represents a major step towards the establishment of a unified Australia-wide inspection system and common product standards for meat. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a special contribution by Australia of $A67.84m towards the Sixth Replenishment of the resources of the International Development Association or IDA as it is commonly called. IDA, established in 1960, is an affiliate of the World Bank, and assists its poorest member countries by providing long-term highly concessionary credits for sound development projects, utilising grant funds provided by donor countries. IDA is the largest and, in our view, the most effective development assistance institution in the world. It is an efficient institution capable of undertaking generally large scale development projects in a technically proficient way while at the same time ensuring that benefits flow either directly or indirectly to the poorest members of society.

The projects which IDA finances are subject to the same rigorous standards of appraisal that the World Bank applies to its ordinary lending operations on near commercial terms. They are systematically monitored and evaluated. A recent overall survey of IDA's experience concludes that IDA lending has been effective in promoting development-not only through the high economic rates of return achieved averaging 18 per cent, but also through its impact on development policies and through its success in developing institutions. This effectiveness was confirmed in a critical study done by the United States Treasury. IDA has shown a great capacity to adapt to changing aid needs; in particular by gradually shifting its lending to the poorest countries and to poor people within these countries. It has also been remarkably successful in attracting increased financial support-at least until very recently. Finally, an enlarged membership, which now includes China, places increasingly heavy pressure in IDA' s development assistance.

IDA's projects cover a wide range of activities, but it is notable that roughly one third are directed to the promotion of agricultural and rural development. Other priority sectors include energy, transport and communications and overall there is a balance between traditional infrastructure projects, such as roads and dams, and newer style projects designed to benefit poorer groups more directly.

Because of the emphasis on the poorest countries, IDA credits are increasingly concentrated on countries outside Australia's immediate region. They serve to complement our own, obviously limited, aid efforts outside our region and in certain instances can be regarded as a substitute for a larger bilateral aid response. I mention here India, which is a major recipient of IDA credits and which is a country whose enormous needs for development assistance far exceed our capacity. I also mention sub-Saharan Africa, the development assistance needs of which are similarly very great, but where it is difficult, particularly for a country like Australia, to ensure that such assistance makes a real contribution.

IDA is currently running up against serious funding difficulties as a result of the decision by the United States Administration to stretch its total contribution to the Sixth Replenishment over four years instead of three. One result, in the absence of offsetting measures of the kind covered by this Bill, is a greatly reduced ability by IDA to enter into project commitments from July 1983 onwards-at a time when IDA's main recipients are still suffering from the adverse effects on their economies of the prolonged world recession and the increasingly difficult environment confronting poorer countries in borrowing on international capital markets.

IDA's funding problems were recognised by the Association's donors in 1982. Consistent with Australia's long standing attitude of strong support for IDA and in company with virtually all other donors, the previous government decided to make a special, additional contribution to IDA equal to one third of its original pledge to the Sixth 3-year Replenishment. This decision was announced at the Annual Meetings of the World Bank's Governors in September 1982. Some twenty donors, including Japan, the Federal Republic of Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Canada, Denmark, Italy, Norway, Sweden and New Zealand made similar decisions.

The present Government wishes to honour this international commitment in the appropriate way, which is the purpose of this Bill. Our contribution to IDA normally takes the form of promissory notes which are then encashed over several years as the Association incurs project expenditures. This legislation will allow Australia to lodge an unqualified instrument of contribution to the Association, which assures the Association that Australia's commitments will be honoured and that the funds required for the encashment are appropriated out of Consolidated Revenue. Encashments relating to this special contribution are not expected to be significant in the current financial year, and allowance has been made in the aid budget.

I would add that this special contribution is very much a 'one-off' response to exceptional needs. We envisage that the Seventh Replenishment of IDA will start in July 1984 and we are heartened by the recent decision of the United States Administration to pass a critical supplementary appropriation for the Sixth Replenishment. The occasion of this year's OECD Ministerial Council Meeting, in May, was used by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to express Australia's strong concern at the funding problems of IDA.

As honourable senators will know, Australia has always been a strong supporter of IDA. There has been general agreement here that IDA is a highly effective channel for the disbursement of development assistance to the poorest countries throughout the world. This Bill provides an opportunity for honourable senators once again to demonstrate their bi-partisan support for IDA and our willingness to recognise, through our support of this institution, the development assistance needs of the poorest developing countries. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

The purpose of this Bill is to enable Australia to consent to an increase in its 'quota' in the International Monetary Fund, and to make the consequent payment. A country's quota in the IMF determines, as well as its financial subscription to the Fund, its voting power in the Fund, its rights to draw from the Fund and its share in any allocations of special drawing rights SDRS, by the Fund. From time to time the Fund reviews the levels of quotas in the light of developments in the world economy, the International Monetary system and changes in the relative economic position of Fund members.

In March this year, in the context of the eighth general review of quotas, the Fund's board of governors approved a resolution proposing a 47.5 per cent increase in the aggregate level of Fund quotas to SDR90 billion. The resolution also proposed that 60 per cent of the overall quota increase be distributed among members in proportion to their relative economic positions in the world and 40 per cent in proportion to their existing quota shares. For this purpose, relative economic positions are measured by a set of formulae which take into account GDP, the level and variability of current external payments and receipts and the level of international reserves. One consequence of this method of distribution is that percentage increases in quotas proposed for individual members vary considerably around the aggregate quota increase of 47.5 per cent. The quota increase will come into effect when members accounting for at least 70 per cent of existing quotas have consented to their proposed increases.

Individual member countries wishing to consent to their proposed quota increases are required to do so by 30 November 1983, and assuming the 70 per cent threshold has been reached by then, to pay for the increase in full by 31 December 1983. As at 2 September 1983, 34 members holding 15.25 per cent of total fund quotas had consented to their proposed increases. The increase in Australia's quota proposed under the review is from SDR1185 million to SADR1619. 2 million, an increase of 36.6 per cent. Section 4 of the Bill approves consent to this increase. Australia's increase of 36.6 per cent is smaller than the average increase of 47.5 per cent. As a result, our share in total quotas will decline from 1.94 per cent to 1.80 per cent. This decline stems from the procedures adopted for distributing the overall quota increase. As I have mentioned, the procedures that have been adopted by the Board of Governors are designed to realign members' quota shares so that they more accurately reflect their relative economic positions. Since, in these terms, Australia's present quota share somewhat overstates our relative economic position in the world, we qualify for a smaller quota increase than the average. As provided for in the IMF articles of agreement and the eighth quota review resolution approved by the Board of Governors, 75 per cent of the additional quota subscription will be paid in Australian dollars and the remainder in SDRS and foreign currency.

Section 5 of the Bill allows for part of the quota subscription to be paid in the form of a non-negotiable, non-interest bearing security as provided in section 7 of the principal Act. The Australian dollar component of the increase is to be paid in this way. The foreign currency and SDRS required to pay the balance of the increase will be purchased from the Reserve Bank; section 6 of the Bill approves an appropriation for the purpose of acquiring foreign currency and the SDRS will be purchased under the standing appropriation of section 5A (6 ) of the principal Act. The purchase of SDRS and foreign currency from the Reserve Bank is a financing transaction and as such has no effect on budget outlays or on the Budget Deficit. The issue of the non-negotiable, non-interest bearing security has no effect on the Consolidated Revenue Fund. It is a promise to pay the fund Australian dollars in the event that the fund needs more of our currency than it presently holds. In that event, which is unlikely, there would be a call on the Consolidated Revenue Fund, but again, no effect on Budget outlays or the deficit.

The timing of the eighth general review of quotas was advanced considerably in the light of concerns about the stability of the international financial system. In supporting the quota resolution in March this year and by consenting to Australia's quota increase now, Australia will help augment the fund's financial resources. These resources have been depleted by a high level of drawings from the fund by its member countries, particularly over the past year or so. The increase in quotas, the Fund's principal source of resources, will enable the Fund to continue to provide temporary balance of payments assistance to members facing serious debt and external payments problems and to promote a stable international monetary system. Such stability is, of course, in Australia's interests. By supporting the quota increase, we will also increase our drawing rights and our entitlement to any allocation of SDRS, as well as protect our voting power in the fund. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to seek parliamentary approval for Australia to take up its entitlement to subscribe to additional shares in the capital stock of the Asian Development Bank. Honourable senators will be aware that the Asian Development Bank is a regional development finance institution. It was established in 1966, with its headquarters in Manila, for the purpose of lending funds, promoting investment and providing technical assistance to developing member countries to foster economic growth and co-operation in the Asian and Pacific regions. Essentially the bank harnesses the financial strength and technical expertise of its developed member countries for the benefit of developing member countries. Capital subscribers provide a pool of funds for lending and a basis for the bank to borrow further funds in world financial markets in larger amounts and on better terms than are available to developing countries.

In addition to its ordinary lending operations, the bank provides loans on highly concessional terms to poorer developing member countries. These are funded from direct contributions by developed member countries to the Asian development fund within the bank. To the end of December 1982, the bank had lent about $US11.5 billion to its developing member countries for projects covering all the major sectors of economic development from major infrastructure developments in the transport, communications, industry and energy sectors to projects in agriculture, education, water supply and urban development. In 1982, the bank approved loans totalling $US1,731 million, of which $US546 million were on highly concessional terms to poorer developing member countries.

Australia's contributions to the Asian Development Bank as at 31 December 1982 comprised: Paid-in capital totalling $US107 million; and contributions to the Asian development fund totalling $US151 million. In addition, as at 31 December 1982 Australia had a contingent liability to the bank in the form of callable capital of $US444 million. The bank has never called on such capital and conducts its operations in such a way as to ensure that that should not become necessary. The callable capital does, however, underpin the bank's borrowing operations. Following an examination of the adequacy of the bank's capital base for its operations during the 1980s, the governors of the Asian Development Bank approved, in April 1983, a resolution increasing the authorised capital stock of the bank by 105 per cent, equal in value to approximately $US9 billion. This should enable the bank to increase the level of its lending to developing member countries in the region. Under the terms of that resolution, 5 per cent of the increase is to be in the form of paid-in shares. The remaining 95 per cent is in the form of callable capital.

Australia voted in favour of the resolution authorising the capital increase. ( The text of the resolution, including the number of shares to which each member is entitled to subscribe, is attached to the explanatory memorandum to this legislation). Members, including Australia, are entitled, but not obligated, to subscribe to this authorised increase. Australia's entitlement under the resolution is to an additional 52,433 shares, comprising 2,622 paid-in shares and 49,811 callable shares. At current exchange rates, this represents $A721 million, of which the paid-in element amounts to some $A36 million. It is envisaged that 40 per cent of the paid-in element would be paid in cash in 5 equal instalments of about $A2.9 million a year from 1983-84 and that the remaining 60 per cent would be in the form of five promissory notes in equal amounts to be encashed over the years 1988 to 1992.

The Bill is similar in form to the Asian Development Bank (Additional Subscription) Act 1977 which provided for Australia's last capital injection to the Asian Development Bank. Essentially the Bill empowers the Treasurer to enter into an agreement with the Asian Development Bank for the purchase by Australia of its entitlement of additional paid-in and callable shares and to issue promissory notes to the bank in payment. The Bill also appropriates the funds necessary to make payments under such agreement. As honourable senators are aware, Australia has been an active supporter of the Asian Development Bank. We have regarded it as an effective and efficient vehicle for regional co-operation and development. Honourable senators will also be aware that this Government attaches particular priority to the needs of developing countries within our region. Accordingly, we believe it to be in Australia's interest to continue this policy of support for the Asian Development Bank by taking up, in full, the increase in the capital subscription to which it is entitled. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the convenience of the Senate may I suggest that we deal with the Medicare Levy Bill, the States ( Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Health Legislation Amendment Bill and the Income Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy) Bill in a cognate fashion.
—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering four Bills, one of which, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, puts in place many of the main features of the Government's Medicare program. The other three Bills , which are I believe Budget Bills, are also necessary for the implementation of that program in full. The Opposition is opposed as a matter of principle to the nationalisation of health insurance and to the extra tax impost contained in the legislation before us. Because we oppose those measures in principle we will vote against them. Let me make it clear: We will vote against the Health Legislation Amendment Bill; we do not intend to vote against Budget Bills. At the same time, if we are unsuccessful at the second reading stage, we will propose some amendments in Committee to correct some defects in the Bills, defects which do pose some particular problems. In my contribution I wish to cover certain areas only. First, I want to state what our objections are to the principles of a centralised state monopoly for health insurance. Secondly, I want to identify some destructive effects which these Bills will have upon individuals. Thirdly, I want to clarify and emphasise that these Bills are not related to better health in Australia and to state where some health problems lay.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition, in approaching this debate in this chamber, works on the premise that we are neither narks nor are we mindless opponents. Furthermore, we are numerate; we can count. We are aware of the public pronouncements by various people who will contribute to the debate. Yet we must, as a responsible Opposition, test, probe and lay bare the details of measures such as this. I want to go through our objections to the principles of a centralised state monopoly. There are many of these objections. It might be helpful to us all if we acknowledge that my colleague, Mr Carlton, in a marathon speech in another place, laid out his objections to this legislation. I have no wish to emulate his 65 minute speech. I do not imagine other senators want to emulate the 65 minute speech given by Dr Blewett. They both set out, I might say, at considerable length-

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in total unanimity with you on that.

—We have total unanimity on that. They set out in great detail many of the arguments. I have no desire to see a filibuster; I see no benefit from a filibuster. But points need to be made if we are to use the review process of the Senate properly. The proposals before us provide for several things. First, they provide for the nationalisation of the health insurance industry. It is worth reminding the Senate that this has been the stated aim of the Australian Labor Party for more than a decade. I remind honourable senators that, in September 1972, Mr Hayden argued as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party is a Socialist Party and its aim as far as medical care is concerned is the establishment of a public enterprise.
His then leader, Mr Whitlam, put it more precisely a couple of months earlier, in July 1972, when he said:

The major act of nationalisation in the traditional sense to be undertaken by a Labor government in the next term will be through the establishment of a single health fund administered by a health insurance commission.

That is fair enough. That is a clear statement of intent which has been persistently held over a decade. These Bills now provide for the implementation of that plan for the provision of a single health fund and for the provision of the administration of health insurance through a single health insurance commission.

Our opposition to this act of nationalisation is opposition on a point of principle. Our spokesman on health matters between 1973 and 1975 made that quite clear. His statements then emphasised, not once, but again and again, the principle of opposition to nationalisation of health insurance. For example, on 5 March 1975, our then spokesman on health matters said:
Our principle has not altered-our position will not alter. The Bill before us is a naked assault by the Minister for Social Security--
let me be quite clear that it is Mr Hayden in the previous Government about whom he is talking-
on the administration and autonomy of private health funds of Australia. It is for that reason that we vigorously oppose it and will continue to oppose it in another place.

That statement set out our objection to the nationalisation of health insurance. It is a difference which separates us philosophically as parties, it is an ideological difference which separates us and it is a point on which we disagree with the Australian Labor Party in principle in terms of our world views and in terms of our views of society. On that basis we will oppose what we see as the nationalisation of health insurance.

There is no need to destroy the health funds. There is no advantage to society from destroying the health funds. Having looked at the arguments put up by the Government now and the Government when it was in opposition and the previous Labor Government as to the advantages of a single health fund for Australia, we believe those advantages either are nonexistent or they are illusory. The act of nationalisation, when it takes place, will create a single state monopoly where none exists now. We believe, we anticipate and we fear that that monopoly will be as unwieldy, as arrogant, as uncaring and as inflexible as all monopolies are . That is a belief which we hold. It underpins the reason that we will vote against the principle behind this legislation.

I dislike monopolies of capital; I dislike monopolies of labour; and I dislike monopolies of government as much or more. I do not believe monopolies are good for society. I do not believe that the creation of a health insurance monopoly will serve society well and neither do my colleagues who make up the Opposition. It is therefore our duty in speaking for a very considerable proportion of the constituency of Australia to make that opposition known and to make it known that we will translate our opposition to the legislation in our vote on the second reading of the Bills.

There is no evidence that the creation of a single monopoly for paying for health care in any way improves health outcome. This has actually been studied. The British National health Service was established in 1947, or close enough to 1947. Social scientists actually conducted research a quarter of a century later . They looked at the outcomes which had followed the first quarter century of the operation of the National Health Service of Great Britain. For those who are keen on looking at the literature, a very important paper by a gentleman named Peter Townsend and another paper dealt with the same point. Townsend considered different socio-economic groups which demographers define as social groups 1 to 5. He looked at their health outcomes in 1947 and he looked at the differences between them in 1947. He was able to demonstrate two things 25 years later: The health status of both groups had improved but the differences in health outcome after a quarter of a century of the British National Health Service were wider than they had been at the beginning. The differences got worse during the first quarter century. The British people were arguing that outcomes would improve and they did not. All the evidence that has been put up has failed to show any narrowing of the gap in health outcomes between different groups of society. It has not shown that a state monopoly, in paying for health care, can lead to better health results.

Many of my socialist friends keep preaching to me that their methods will produce better outcomes. I ask them to show me, from experience, from those nations which have accepted a single system of payment, how that has occurred. Experience has not revealed that it has. Surely that should trouble the planners . Surely they should be troubled by the difficulties which are occurring in Canada with its scheme. Surely they should be worried by the financial difficulties that the Canadian scheme has got into. They should be worried by the difficulties within the British national health service. They should be worried by the financial difficulties facing the American system, limited though it may be. If there is no evidence of better outcomes then the basic raison d' etre, the basic justification, for introducing such a system falls. I submit that only by improving outcomes, only by improving what goes on in society, can we really justify the major changes which are being put on us today.

Those are not our only objections. There are other objections. First, there is to be the imposition of a significant new tax upon income, a tax which does not presently exist, a new one per cent income tax which everyone will pay after 1 January. It is expected to yield $1 billion. It starts at one per cent. Labor, in 1975 I believe, started its levy at that stage and was offering it at 1.35 per cent. I have no doubt that the levy rate, starting at one per cent, will rise higher as the costs of the scheme emerge and as the inadequacy of the funding emerges and that we can expect that this extra tax impost starting at one per cent will go higher. Not only that, but also will there be a double payment for families. That payment will be one per cent on the income of all working people. Where there are two income families there will be two payments to be made. Many people are not aware that each working person will have to pay one per cent of his or her income come 1 February.

There is a third objection in addition to the nationalisation question, and that relates to the position of Queenslanders. Let everyone understand that Queenslanders will be paying a new tax for the provisions of services which they now get within Queensland at no cost at all. It will be a new tax in pursuit of socialisation and nationalisation to pay for something which at the present time they get for nothing. I am sure that my Queensland colleagues, when they contribute to this debate, will have plenty to say about that. I notice that Senator Bjelke-Petersen is to speak in this debate. I hope that she sets out what the costs will be to Queenslanders, costs that they do not have to pay today. I hope that all Queenslanders going to the election in that State in a few weeks will remember that they are faced with an Australian Labor Party impost to pay for free hospitals which they have known and enjoyed for many years.

The fourth objection-and I have alluded to this already-is that we think that the Medicare tax rate is likely to rise over time. The fifth objection, apart from nationalisation, relates to the large extra cost which the levy will not cover. On current funding, if Medicare is to cost $1.7 billion in the first year and if the levy is to raise $1 billion, we think that there will be an extra $ 700m to be funded from Consolidated Revenue, in other words, to be funded from other means of taxation. The sixth objection which we have to this program is that it will lead to a net loss of jobs. How great that will be we cannot be certain but we think it will be a net loss of jobs within the health insurance industry of the order of 2,000. Not only that, but also will there be a temporary dislocation, a temporary job loss of many more than that.

Let me remind honourable senators that, if this Bill becomes an Act, the Health Insurance Commission will be recruiting people progressively, from now to February, for its scheme which will begin on 1 February. It will not be able to do all its recruiting after February. The health funds, with continuing obligations up to February, may be shedding some staff now but the main shedding of staff will occur after February. Many of the people in the health insurance industry will find that, when they lose their jobs at their fund, many of the jobs in the Health Insurance Commission have already been taken up. There will be temporary dislocation which will mean difficulties in employment for many more people than the 2,000 whose jobs will go. The net loss of 2,000 will be accompanied by dislocation of many more people than that.

The other significant point to be made is that pensioners will suffer because of a consumer price index fiddle associated with this situation. If health costs come out of the CPI, the CPI will be artificially depressed in 1984. This, of course , will reflect itself in lower increases in the pension, dependent as it is upon movement in the CPI. Because of the introduction of this Medicare scheme and because health costs will be removed from the CPI, pensioners can expect to lose something like 2.6 per cent effect on the CPI and there will be a consequent loss to pensioners of the amounts they could have expected to receive by way of pension rises in 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that we keep up inflation?

—They will get lower pensions than they would have had if the 2.6 per cent had stayed in. What I am suggesting to Senator Crowley is that she should address the question and if pensioners are to be worse off than they would have been, she may wish to consider means to ensure that they will not be worse off. It is difficult enough living on the pension, but for them to look forward to a lower pension rise than they would have had under existing circumstances is something that will concern pensioner organisations and age pensioners and pensioners will feel cheated by what is happening and by what is happening to them. So we have a number of objections to the scheme. As I say, I do not wish to rehearse the arguments advanced by Mr Carlton in the House of Representatives. The objections are both objections of principle to the idea of nationalisation of health insurance and objections to some of the details which are consequential.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to spend a few moments saying a little about the health of Australian society. We get little enough opportunity to do so. This debate is supposedly about health and I think I can say some things which may attract agreement from most parts of the chamber. Health outcomes are more important than are the processes for providing services. Our debates in Australia, all the passion, all the arguments that are going on, the all night sittings in the House of Representatives, were not directed to health. They were directed to a means of paying for medical services. There is all the difference in the world between methods of payment and the health outcomes which occur and I think Senator Haines, in the question she asked today in Question Time, really emphasised the differences between how one pays for things and what one gets in terms of health outcomes. It is not inappropriate to say a little about health and health outcomes in this debate. I remind honourable senators that we are going down the road of equating service provision, of paying people, with health itself. Of course that assumption is not so. Aaron Wildavsky, a very prominent American, I think known to some people in this chamber, said in one of his writings:
According to the great equation, medical services equal health.
He went on to say:
But the great equation is wrong.

I remind honourable senators for a few moments that we ended dental caries amongst most Australian children simply by fluoridating water. We did not do it by providing or paying for services in a better way. We get dental caries now only in those communities where water remains unfluoridated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brisbane.

—In Brisbane, Senator Colston says. That is a pity. Policies directed to service provision-in other words dental services-were irrelevant in the end to the solution of the underlying problem. I mention a couple more examples. We ended poliomyelitis in this country-we got rid of it from our society-not by finding different ways of paying for services or concentrating upon inventing better iron lungs or training people but by introducing Salk and Sabin vaccines. We did not do it by providing services or paying for them. Policies which were directed towards service payment were irrelevant in the solution of the underlying health problem. Of course we have to direct our minds to the payment for services. But we must remember that it is largely irrelevant to the resolution of some of the great health problems of our society. We know where the great health problems lie in Australia. Many of them are preventable. I remind honourable senators that a Dr Knowles, an eminent American medical educator, when writing about that country-he could have been talking about Australia-said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many Americans have come to look on 'sloth, gluttony, alcoholic intemperance, reckless driving, sexual frenzy and smoking' as constitutional rights, and they've come to expect government-financed 'cures' for all the unhappy consequences.

He pinpoints in that one sentence many of the problems in Australia. They are problems which will not be eased even by the most efficient method of paying for or providing medical services. It is not until we come to grips with some of the underlying issues that we can really look to a healthier society. We know the damage tobacco does; we are loth as a nation to take effective action. We know what causes much of the carnage on the roads, but we seem overly sensitive to club and industry interests when it comes to doing anything about it or to putting effective programs in place. We would welcome some more emphasis on measures to address these problems. We need more of the 'Life. Be In It', 'Quit for Life' and 'Belt up and Live' programs-programs with which we can try to prevent the need for some of the services. We want that kind of emphasis as well as programs directed to how one pays. It is important in the Medicare debate that this aspect of our concern for health not be forgotten or left out while we consider health payments, health insurance, health deductibles and schemes like that. They have not and they cannot deliver better community outcomes themselves . It is because I am concerned about these things that I thought it worth putting them into the debate.
We desire to see the second reading debate come to a conclusion sometime in the not too distant future so that we can get some resolution of the matters of principle. Therefore I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
'the Senate declines to give the Bill a second reading as it is of the opinion that the Australian system of health care delivery and financing should be based on-

(a) the private professional practice of doctors and other health professionals charging a fee for service supported by a private sector insurance system, and sympathetic government assistance to the aged and the disadvantaged; and

(b) public and private provision of hospital and other institutional facilities and community health care, accessible to private practitioners for the treatment of their patients, supported by a private sector insurance system, and sympathetic government assistance to the aged and the disadvantaged'.

That is the same amendment as was moved in another place by my colleague Mr Carlton. Let me reiterate: We oppose these Bills because they offend us on principle. We will vote against the main Bill, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, at the second reading and will vote for the amendment I have just moved. If the Bills do proceed to the Committee stage, we will then raise again and in a reasoned way five or six small particular matters which we believe require amendment if the Bills are to operate effectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike Senator Baume, I am delighted to support this Medicare legislation. I am delighted to be a part of a government that has the opportunity to reintroduce a health system that ought to have remained in place following its establishment in 1973. It is quite remarkable that, 10 years later, we have come back to re-doing what had been very well established in the first place. This reintroduction will allow for the removal of some of the bumps that the system had after its original passage.

SPEECH.PARA: I address myself briefly to a few points raised by Senator Baume. I cannot take issue with him on a matter of principle. He clearly says that is what he believes; I leave him with his beliefs. I do take issue with him when he bends the evidence. The Health Insurance Commission is not about a single fund for health care; it is about a single fund for basic health and medical care. There is no way that the private health funds will not be able to continue. In fact, the private health funds have been encouraged to continue by quite a few of the agreements that have been reached between the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and themselves. Senator Baume claimed that having a private health insurance industry would be very useful. He said it would be an efficient, splendid thing to have in our society because it does all these wonderful things for people, and it is important to have a multiplicity of funds. Yet one of the concessions that the funds have required, and which we are pleased to allow them, is the possibility of amalgamation between smaller funds, to enable them to rationalise their industry.

Senator Baume also introduced the possibility of this matter being a distraction from the question of health. I can only utterly agree with him, and remind him again that, had his Government not broken down and disbanded Medibank , we could have been pursuing health questions for the last decade instead of blowing in the wind, as we have, with five different health arrangements in between the introduction of Medibank and this reintroduction of a similar sort of system in Medicare. In fact, the community health program, also introduced under the previous Labor Government, could have been far further advanced and been addressing itself to exactly what its policy claims; that is, preventive programs and good health.

Senator Baume also claimed that discussions about health insurance have nothing to do with the health of people. I ask him to ring up some of those many people who are very anxious about where they will find the money to go to the doctor. Anxiety, sir, is a sort of sickness. Further, I refer to those many people who, because they cannot afford private insurance, have delayed going to the doctor until they are much sicker than they would have been had they been able to go earlier. His Government has a lot to answer for. As well, if in fact we had not been distracted from the health debate that could have progressed over the last decade, we would have been able to develop what this Government is going to introduce-that is, an efficient and proper occupational health and safety program which directs itself very much to the prevention of illness and sickness in industry instead of fixing it up after the event. The Opposition does not have a leg to stand on.

I am delighted to support the Medicare Levy Bill and I am also aware that the community is delighted at the introduction of Medicare. I quote from a couple of editorials. The Adelaide Advertiser on Wednesday, 25 May 1983, stated:

Medicare, rooted in principles that must be expected from a Socialist Government, is a resurrection, modified by experience, of the original Whitlam Medibank, that social vision that was to become so maligned, mangled and finally murdered.

Health insurance in Australia is a messy patchwork of computerised band-aids and a public bewilderment; Medicare at least promises simplicity. On the philosophy that the whole community should pay for health care according to means, and receive health care according to needs, every taxpayer will be levied 1 per cent of income from February 1 and everybody will be entitled to medical and basic hospital treatment paid for by Medicare, which an expanded Medibank Private will administer.
On 25 July, the Australian stated:

It is clear that Labor's commitment to bring in Medicare, almost as an article of faith, has sunk in. It is obvious the Government will not be swayed from its aim-and it has also been realised that a publicly administered health insurance scheme is not necessarily the first step towards socialised medicine that the more ferocious opponents once branded it. Indeed, Medicare has worthy social aims and, as it is inevitable, its smooth implementation can only be to the country's benefit.

Neither the Australian nor the Advertiser is a newspaper known for its radical approach to things or for its appreciation of what is widely known in the community which in this case is that Medicare is coming, it is almost upon us and all Australians will be delighted to discover when it is implemented how it will help them.

I turn now to some of the economic benefits that will flow to individuals. The first great advantage of Medicare is that it is universal. Every Australian, including the two million currently not covered, will be covered for all basic health costs. Any health insurance scheme that allows two million Australians to have no health insurance cover is, I think, a disgrace. The next important advantage to individuals is that payment for health costs under this scheme will be according to ability to pay. Currently, a family on $400 a week would be paying $14.50 a week for its basic health care. Under the Medicare system it will pay $4. Further, a family now pays $14.50 a week whether it earns $400 a week or $1,000 a week.

Another considerable advantage to people is that there will be a considerable saving on health care costs. This saving can then be spent on other consumer items. For their one per cent levy on taxable income people in Australia will receive an 85 per cent reimbursement of the schedule fee and will pay a maximum amount of $10 for any one medical item. All public hospital accommodation and medical attention will be free. This will cover dental surgery, optometry, radiology, pathology, surgery, diagnosis, in-patient and out-patient services and other specialist services. However, because this Government is well aware of the problems of people on low incomes, it gives an exemption from the levy to people on lower incomes. Single people may earn up to $128.80 a week before they have to pay any levy. Couples may earn $214.25 a week. There will be a further allowance of $21.15 for each dependent child. As well, pensioner card holders and health care card holders will continue to be covered without making any contribution towards the levy.

In addition, there will be no gap insurance. We need to know that the non- payment of gap insurance will advantage individuals. In 1980 the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals found that if people paid for gap insurance they would have to pay $2 on top of the 100 per cent schedule fee rebate, instead of $2 for the difference between the Medicare benefit and the schedule fee on standard GP consultations. They would have to pay a premium as well for the gap cover. The only people really advantaged by that system would be the doctors. Gap insurance also does nothing to contain overall health costs. Indeed, it is positively an inducement to creating more health care costs. If people choose to have private hospital insurance they will be able to buy it under Medicare arrangements for an estimated $5 a week. A family on $300 a week would have to pay $3 for its Medicare levy and $5 for private hospital insurance. That still means that its total health care cost a week would be $8. Even if we take into account the $4 forgone on the rebate, it would still be $2 or $3 better off than it is under the present scheme.

Economic benefits will also accrue to individual doctors. For a start, if any doctor chooses to bulk bill, he loses all fear of, or occurrence of, bad debts. In previous studies administration costs in general practice have been estimated at about 15 per cent because of revenue forgone and the costs of following up bad debts. Many doctors are very happy to take the 85 per cent as a very reasonable estimate. Bulk billing also reduces overheads in terms of general administration of practices. It reduces payment delays and takes care of administrative problems so that more time can be spent in actual medical practice. Further, because it seems to be very fashionable to bash doctors, I take the opportunity to say that most medical practitioners in this country have a real concern for their patients and are not in the rip-off business. The 6 or 7 per cent who are in that business have disgraced the whole profession. Many doctors are very concerned about patients who cannot afford to pay or have trouble finding the money for health care costs. They know that bulk billing, which will advantage them, will also advantage their patients. This relieves the doctor of that concern.

There are other economic benefits that are more part of a macroeconomic view of things. The principal benefits of the Medicare proposal, with self-funding of the health scheme through the one per cent levy and rearrangement of health insurance subsidies, will be a distinct advantage. It is interesting to note that, when Medibank was originally established, it had to be run with funds from Consolidated Revenue. It is no wonder that the Liberal Opposition gets its figures wrong. It was part of the Senate that refused to allow the levy that might have made Medibank more rational when it was originally introduced; instead, there was a run on Consolidated Revenue.

Senator Baume asked where we would find the other $700m. One of the things about Minister Blewett is that he is remarkably adequate in finding facts and figures and sharing them with the community. He has actually spelt out that there will probably be a return of more than $700m. There will be the $600m from the taxable rebate to private health fund members coming to the Government, as well as the $100m that goes currently to subsidise private health funds and helps to keep their contribution rates down. Both of these present costs to the Government add up very nicely to the $700m Senator Baume needs, so he need not worry any more.

Because the one per cent levy will be a saving for most people in terms of their health costs, there will be more money in people's pockets to spend. It may not be a large amount of money in our terms, but for many families it will be considerable. That kind of spending on goods other than health care can contribute to a consumer-led recovery from our rather dreadful economic situation at the moment. Another important part of this policy is in line with another Government aim, that is, of a more equitable redistribution of wealth. Those who have greater financial resources will be contributing more than those who have fewer resources. This Medicare policy is based on our Government's philosophy of 'from each according to his or her means'. The taxpayer's dollars will be allocated to areas of greatest need. As well, the introduction of Medicare with the levy is expected to reduce the consumer price index by 2 or 2. 6 per cent in the first half of 1984. That will be an enormous gain in terms of the economic recovery that is needed in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except for pensioners.

—Once again Senator Baume raises this remarkable idea that if we keep inflation up it will advantage pensioners. That is a way of thinking that the rest of us do not buy at all. The pensioners are not stupid. They realise that if inflation falls their purchasing power is extended. They are not so stupid as the Liberal Opposition regards them.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, Medicare is in direct accord with the trade union movement's aim to assist lower and middle income earners. I quote from a joint statement issued by the Federal Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, and the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Cliff Dolan:
The smooth and successful introduction of Medicare on February 1, 1984 is an intrinsic part of the prices and incomes accord between the Australian Government and the ACTU.
One of the major elements of the prices and incomes accord was the establishment of a single public health fund financed by an equitable levy on taxable income.
The ACTU supports this as the fairest and most cost efficient way of operating a nation wide health fund plan.
This view was reiterated and expanded at the National Economic Summit Conference when the communique stated:
'The Summit notes the announced health policies of the Government and believes that it is imperative that at the Commonwealth level a stable system should be introduced as a matter of urgency.'
The communique further stated:
'The unions reaffirm their commitment that they will accept an offset in wage increases on account of the health insurance scheme.'

I should have thought that that was a very significant part of our economic program. It is also a co-ordinated health policy whereby the Federal Government is the main administrator and has some considerable say about national policy guidelines, but responsibility and finance are shared with the States as appropriate. The States will be reimbursed fairly after removal of public hospital charges. The agreement will also require monitoring measures of hospital admissions, financial and operational arrangements to achieve economies in this area to be taken up by the States by mid-1985. Currently only South Australia and Tasmania can, for example, give the cost of hospital beds in their States as part of the previous cost sharing arrangements. After 1985 that information will be available from all States. That will lead to the possibility of better planning and rationalisation of funding and services.

The Medicare program can be looked at in terms of its social benefits. It is a simple, fair and affordable system of universal health coverage. Its simplicity really needs to be dwelt upon. It means that it will be delivered to those who most need it. The low income earners will no longer be faced with the bureaucratic complexity of the health card system or even calculating their incomes to find out what they are eligible for. Currently it is estimated that there are about half a million people in Australia who are entitled to the health care card and who are not using it. The program does not disadvantage the articulate because it is simple; it advantages the less able in our community. Not only are we talking about people who may not speak English as a first language; we are also talking about people who are belted down with poverty, with a lack of education and with a build up of misfortunes. Those people do not sometimes know what their rights are. Further, it is not stigmatising. At the moment we have tiers of people in this community who are eligible for different things according to their incomes, when their income level is not dependent on their own ability, but on the circumstances of high unemployment. I think it is reasonable to quote Bevan at this stage. He rejected such proposals of stigmatising and health means testing for income payments when he was talking about the introduction of the British health scheme in the late 1940s. He said:

Where a patient claimed he could not afford treatment, an investigation would have to be made into his means, with all the personal humiliation and vexation involved . . . and these are the least of its shortcomings. The really objectionable feature is the creation of a two standard health service, one below and one above the salt . . . The essence of a satisfactory health service is that the rich and the poor are treated alike, that poverty is not a disability and wealth is not advantage.

That is exactly what Medicare is going to achieve. It is also an easy system because the coverage is automatic. The payments will be deducted weekly, fortnightly or monthly, depending on how one's wage or salary is paid, or else from an annual payment of income tax. As well it will be clearly categorised as a seperate payment. It will not be a levy by stealth, but it will be obvious to people that their one per cent is taken out, and they will know how much it is. Also the Medicare card will be available for all people. People in the community can choose whether they want a family card or an individual card. No doubt that little point will come up in the Committee of the Whole and I will leave my comments on that until then. Medicare will be affordable to all because it is based on the ability of people to pay rather than on a flat rate payment. In fact, those who are most in need will be exempt from any contributions at all. The discrimination between differences in benefits currently allows some pensioners to earn more than low income earners and still retain concession cards. It is estimated that the change in Medicare arrangements will further exempt 200,000 people.

As well, despite the comments of Senator Baume, the Medicare arrangements will contribute to the funding of the community health services. These are a less costly alternative to a more institutional service and their main aim and focus is a preventive health delivery. As I said before, if the Government had left arrangements 10 years ago alone, we would be much further along the way of developing our community health services and our preventive health program. Medicare is universally equitable because it is a basic right that will be provided to all Australians-all people who reside here, visitors of six months duration or more and any Australian overseas who needs medical attention. It will particularly help those many disadvantaged groups in Australia-Aboriginal people, migrants, women and children.

I now turn to the medical benefits. The health cover to all Australians is basically a humane scheme. It will be established under the Health Insurance Commission. I find the objections raised at this point by some of the members of the Opposition quite remarkable. They have said in the past that if people do not have to pay anything, they will overuse the service. I can just imagine the millions of Australians who now know that they do not have to find the cash in their pockets rushing off to the doctors' surgeries because that is a beaut thing to do in the afternoon! That is a ridiculous understanding of how Australian people behave. They do not do that. In 1975 an Australian Medical Association study confirmed that there was no increase in services under the period of Medibank compared with before or after it was established. The increase in service use showed no special hiccup during the period of Medibank. In fact most people appreciated very well their one per cent levy. They know what it is about. They are not stupid, as the Liberal Party Opposition keeps insisting. In fact, if honourable senators want to follow that argument more closely there is sometimes an inducement to people who have private health insurance to get their money's worth. It may well be that private insurance leads to more use or overuse of health services than a health levy. It is not insurance; it is an establishment of funding of a whole health system so that anybody in Australia who needs health care can get it without the financial burden at the time of the need. Because of the system being available from that levy there will be no need to postpone early attending of doctors in respect of illnesses. In fact, it may lead to a reduction in hospitalisation because of early intervention on the part of people.

Senator Baume said that how health is paid for does not make any difference to the health care of Australians. I ask him about the people who get anxious when they cannot find money to pay for health care. I ask him about the number of people who have been risking bad debts over the last year or so and who duck away from doctors and have to shop for doctors because they are ashamed to go back and admit that they cannot pay their bills. That kind of worry is not healthy. Another claim that is made about Medicare is that it will thrust everybody into the public hospital system. The facts deny this. I quote from page 782 of the the House of Representatives Hansard. My learned colleague Dr Charlesworth-also a man of experience in these things-said last Wednesday:

The latest Fraser health scheme-the fifth scheme-introduced on 1 September 1981 resulted in a massive increase in bed charges in public hospitals from $50 a day in August 1981 to $110 a day in September 1982. That was an increase of 120 per cent in 12 months.
I will leave out what he said to the honourable members opposite. He went on to say:

. . . Again honourable members opposite choose to ignore the facts. Bed occupancy during the year of the original Medibank scheme was 319 bed days per 1 ,000. Last year the bed occupancy rate was 292 bed days per 1,000 in private hospitals.

In other words, under the private scheme there was less use. So I am not at all sure what point the Opposition wishes to make about that. The other important aspect of the Health Insurance Commission is the significant gains that will follow having a single computer for data collection. It seems that the main reason for this will be to pursue doctors who may be practising fraud or overservicing. I think that is a very important point and it has to be considered. I believe that the most important advantage of the single computer for data collection will be, first to the patients in terms of better service for medical costs; and secondly, and importantly, the epidemiological information that it will throw up about health and the distribution of services for health around Australia. It is information that people often say they desperately need. I can only agree with them. I think the single data collection will provide that. It will provide a first step to the more important data collection that we need. For example, we are often asked: What work do people do and how does that work contribute to their ill health? Whilst I do not think the steps have already been taken to collect that data through the single Health Insurance Commission computer, I am sure that the program will be much more manageable through that step. I urge my medical colleagues to consider that at some stage. I will certainly be pushing for it.

There are some legal benefits flowing from the Medicare system. I have just mentioned one. The computer will provide evidence of medical fraud and allow much easier pursuit of it. There is also the possibility of checking on overservicing by doctors. Both will be a great gain in terms of containing the costs of the health bill to the community. There are other changes but I think they are best left until the debate at the Committee stage.

Another point that has been offered as criticism of the introduction of Medicare is that people do not know about it, they are confused, and the matter has not really been debated. I find this claim quite remarkable particularly in light of the pieces of paper, the words printed and the many speeches that have been given by, firstly, shadow Minister and subsequently Minister Blewett and also by the Labor Party during and prior to the election campaign.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Allegations Against Victorian Minister for Police and Emergency Services- Queensland-Transfer of Technology Contracts for Underdeveloped Countries

PROCTEXT.PARA: Allegations Against Victorian Minister for Police and Emergency Services- Queensland-Transfer of Technology Contracts for Underdeveloped Countries

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to refer to the adjournment debate that occurred in the other place on Thursday, 15 September. In that debate, Mr Aldred, the recently elected member for Bruce, launched an unwarranted attack on the Victorian Police Minister, Race Mathews. Mr Mathews is my local State member. He is also Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Minister for the Arts and a former member of this institution as the member for Casey from 1972 to 1975. I must say that one of the reasons he is the member for Oakleigh is that, when a vacancy occurred for endorsement to that seat, we as locals searched right throughout the Australian Labor Party for the best available candidate. We looked Victoria wide and we requested Mr Mathews to move into the electorate and to contest the seat, which he did. In other words, we went right throughout Victoria to find the person we regarded as the best candidate, a person of immense integrity. This is the person who was attacked the other night on virtually no evidence whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: The accusation against Mr Mathews is that he is pre-empting the poker machine inquiry in Victoria. The evidence is a supposed transcript of a conversation between Mr Mathews and another Labor Party member in Mr Mathews's driveway. In his attack, Mr Aldred said:
. . . on Sunday, 5 May-

That is how he started off his attack. For a start, there was no 'Sunday, 5 May' this year. This individual, this member of Parliament, cannot even tell what day it is. Nevertheless, he mentions the date '5 May'. Mr Mathews consulted his diary and found that he left home early in the morning and arrived back late at night. Under these circumstances, it would have been very unlikely that he could have had a discussion in his driveway. But then, of course, Mr Aldred shifted his ground and said: 'Oh, no, it is really Sunday 8 May'. Mr Aldred produced a transcript. The moment I read the transcript I knew it was false.

Let me put this on the record: Mr Mathews today in the State Parliament and elsewhere has denied that the conversation ever took place. The other party to the conversation, Mr 'V'-I know his identity but there is no need to reveal it here-has also publicly denied that any such conversation took place. I think it is indicative of the veracity of Mr Aldred's claims that he did not at any stage consult with Race Mathews. Nevertheless, this transcript has been put in the Hansard record in another place. First of all, it claims that Mr 'V' is an ex- Labor Party president of the local branch. That was never true. He has never held that position; he has never been a Labor Party president. The transcript goes on to claim that Mr 'V' is a bingo centre operator. He has never held such a position either.

I believe that, for several reasons, the transcript is totally unrealistic. Reference is made in the transcript to the member for Glenhuntly as Mr Gerry Vaughan. I have known Dr Gerard Vaughan for 12 years and no one in the last 12 years has referred to him as Gerry, the same as no one really refers to me as ' Bob'. I am referred to as 'Robert', it is just a matter of personal choice. It is quite clear that within the Labor Party in the last 12 years no one-Mr 'V' or anyone else-has ever referred to Dr Vaughan as 'Gerry'. The second factor that makes me cast doubt on the veracity of the transcript is that there is reference to Mr Mathews using the terms 'centre' and 'right' to indicate groups within the Labor Party. They are terms that are used by two groups only-the Press and the Liberal Party. In the Labor Party in Victoria-and we acknowledge that these groups do operate-they are called the Labor unity group or the independents. We never refer to them as 'centre' or 'right'. That again indicates that this is a totally bogus document.

How did Mr Aldred come by this document? Surely he would have checked it. Was it recorded? If the alleged coversation was recorded at night, I point out that I have seen Cole Crescent and I know how dark the driveway is. Therefore, what was supposed to have been said could not have been written down by another party . Are we to suppose that there was electronic surveillance? I doubt that this was the case, especially in these times. One could not admit to that. What I am saying is that I do not think that the transcript is at all genuine. I think it is up to Mr Aldred to come out and say who wrote it and how he obtained it so that we can see whether it has any truth to it at all.

This is the third time that Mr Aldred has achieved some sort of publicity in his parliamentary career. The first grand occasion was in the parliamentary dining room where he stacked up seven glasses and poured wine over them splashing all the guests and the table. That is the first time he hit the national headlines. It was not something to be very proud about. But the second time-and this relates to the latest incident-was when he produced the great crime report. With the honourable member for Wantirna in Victoria, Mr Don Saltmarsh, Mr Aldred produced a massive document that described how organised crime existed in Australia. This was an earth-shattering document. However, when they went on television they could not reveal any of it. They dropped back to the old technique of saying: 'There is a royal commission set up' or 'a crimes commission is set up' and 'We will refer it to them but we cannot release any of the evidence at the moment'. I must say that rather uncharitably at the time I thought that no evidence existed and that it was a bogus report. However, they referred it to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police who is supposed to have taken absolutely no action on it.
Could I say what Mr Mathews said in the Parliament about this crimes report? He said:
The judgement of the senior police who investigated those allegations suggests that Aldred's disgraceful behaviour last week was totally in character.

He went on to say that the official police comment on this report said that it was 'a spurious document which is baseless in fact and ridiculous in content'. The senior police officer went on in his evaluation to say:
It could well be described as one of the best examples of defamatory libel seen in this century.

They were the allegations made a couple of years ago, described as one of the greatest pieces of defamatory libel. This reflects how much we can believe this latest set of allegations.
