SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of concern to all people interested in Third World development, whether for humanitarian reasons or because they believe, as I do, that the future prosperity of the whole world will depend on continuing development of less developed countries. The matter relates to contracts for the transfer of technology from the developed world to the developing world and the development of an international code on the transfer of technology transactions. The urgency is that next month the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development will sponsor a fifth negotiating conference on the code which has had a tortured history over the last decade. Failure at this conference to resolve outstanding differences may well spell the end to negotiations and perhaps would be the most major setback for those who support the concept of a new international economic order.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise the subject now because Australia has played a significant role in the negotiating process and perhaps with a more up-tempo approach is in a position to affect significantly the outcome of the final conference. This follows not only from our position as a major exporter and importer of technology, which means that we do not have a vested interest in protecting the interests of either side, but also from the fact that although we are grouped with the developed countries in the negotiating process, we nevertheless are held in high regard by the developing countries. We are seen as genuine and not opportunistic , much of which reputation I believe can be traced back to the attitudes of the previous Prime Minister on redressing the North-South dichotomy, and the understanding and practical assistance which we have given to the developing countries, particularly in Africa and the Pacific region.

I regret that, although the public servants in the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Department of Trade, the Attorney-General's Department and other departments have battled away for years on this subject, I can find no ministerial statements giving credence to the importance of the matter or of the contribution we can make. I believe that it is time the Government rectified that omission and lifted the issue to the level of public profile that it deserves. I hope that by this contribution I might stimulate the Parliament and the relevant Ministers to give the matter more direct attention.

The concept of the code is premised on the belief that technological development plays a major part in economic development, that the developed countries are a storehouse of scientific and technical knowledge and that a transfer of such technology to less developed countries on reasonable terms will therefore contribute substantially to their economic growth and development. However, developing countries, because of their relative economic weakness in negotiations for such contracts, have often had to pay unreasonable costs for such technology and to accept transfers often on unduly severe terms that are one sided and impose unnecessary restrictions which would constitute restrictive practices or monopolistic abuses prohibited under anti-trust legislation in the transferor developed country.

For example, a study of 409 contracted agreements in Andean countries showed 317 which contained a total prohibition of exports, and most of the remaining agreements permitted exports to limited areas only. Additionally, there has been a growing awareness that technology being transferred is often unsuitable to national development plans and aspirations. As the development of local technological capabilities has become a more conscious objective, the imported technology has been found more often than not to be inappropriate. Incidentally, it is estimated that only 2 per cent of the world's research and development is carried out in developing countries.

Technology transfer is not a universal panacea for economic growth in the Third World. One must not disregard the importance of labour, capital, education and training. Reflecting the view of one commentator that technology transfer has ' reinforced an inequitable framework for distributing the fruits of economic progress and promoting the welfare of a small elite, whose consumption and general lifestyle closely emulated those of the elite in developed countries', one must not forget the need for socio-economic reform. Few argue, however, that more ready access to more appropriate technology on reasonable terms and conditions cannot, and has not the potential to, play a major role in economic growth and improved standards of living in recipient nations.

A code that will restructure existing relationships between suppliers and recipients of technology to achieve such objectives must therefore be of considerable value and importance. This has been generally recognised by the world community, at least since 1974, when it was included in the program of action on the establishment of a new international economic order. It was reinforced by the United Nations Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States , which demanded such a code of conduct and increased transmissions of technology to the Third World.

The scheme of the proposed code is, on the one hand, to regulate the transfer of technology transaction, that is, the agreement of transfer between the parties immediately concerned and, on the other hand, to place substantive obligations upon States to achieve the code's wider objectives. As between the parties to the contract the code specifies practices and arrangements involving transfer of technology which are deemed undesirable, the restrictive trade practices provisions, and, provides for certain guarantees, responsibilities and obligations to be accepted by each of the parties to the transaction. In relation to the obligation by states, the code, first provides a guide for regional regulation of technology transactions; secondly, provides for the special treatment of developing countries, establishing the link between contracts for transfer of technology and programs for development assistance; and, thirdly, provides for the international co-operative activities of States to facilitate the flow of technology and the growth of technology capabilities of developing countries. But alas, despite enormous effort by many individuals over the succeeding decade, the code remains a heavily bracketed draft.

Accepting the desirability of these objectives, what are the apparently insurmountable difficulties which I believe Australia can play a role in overcoming? As might be imagined, the major areas of dispute go well beyond the detail of the code and raise fundamental questions. The philosophical differences between the negotiating parties were evident from the time of the first draft and they still remain. The developing countries view technology as part of the universal human heritage and assert that all countries have a right of access to technological developments in order to improve their standards of living. Developed countries rather see technology as an asset, for which payment has been made, and that an enterprise is entitled to market. Through the major differences in the draft code, this difference of approach can be seen.

Thus, there has been a reluctance by developed countries to accept that the code should consist of more than guidelines which are voluntary and non-binding. On the other hand, developing countries have maintained in principle that an internationally binding instrument is the only form capable of effectively regulating the transfer of technology. Similarly, group B or developed countries have sought to limit the code to truly international transactions, stating that the technology must be transferred across national boundaries. Developing countries, looking to the purpose, have delved deeper, arguing that the code should apply to transferors located in the recipient country but controlled by a foreign entity.

The same difference of philosophy is evident in relation to the restrictive practices provisions. Developed countries have held the position that we should avoid restrictive practices which unreasonably restrain trade and adversely affect the international flow of technology. Developing nations see the restrictions not so much in the light of anti-trust but as practices which are essentially reprehensible because they are unfair in themselves and represent the result of undue influence by a strong supplying party over a weaker receiving party.

Developing countries go so far as to say that the competent authorities of the technology acquiring country, in exceptional circumstances, must have the authority under the code to decide that it is in the public interest to disregard the restrictive practices provisions. This unilateral assessment has been unacceptable to the developed world. Consistent with the same approach, developed countries hold that the parties should have the freedom to choose the applicable law and the national forum before which disputes will be brought. The position of developing countries is, however, that the law of the acquiring country is the law applicable to matters relating to public policy and sovereignty. Anything short of such a position has been interpreted as an abrogation of the sovereignty of the recipient party and, therefore, undesirable .

What has been happening in the meantime is that the slow pace of negotiations and the seemingly insurmountable differences of principle have encouraged developing countries, no longer willing to do business under the vendor's terms, to consider legislation, at both national and regional levels, which will secure technology transfers on terms more favourable to the realisation of their domestic priorities. This has become the trend. I do not wish to delay the Senate for too long but as one example of regional action I refer to the Andean Foreign Investment Code, under which a contract dealing with the importation of technology patents and trademarks must be submitted for examination and approval by each member nation. Thus, an assessment of the interests of the member nations can be made, particularly as to whether the proposed transfer is in violation of the investment code. A national example is that of the Mexican investment codes, which similarly regulate transfer of technology.

I suggest that regional and national codes are a poor second best. From the point of view of the transferor, he has been able to provide no input into the terms of the restriction. From the point of view of the transferee, because the codes do not include the transferor, such countries run the risk of blocking out the good with the bad and, therefore, retarding development. Therefore, the arguments for a universal code remain strong. The critical questions relate to how to break the stalemate, how to reduce the philosophical differences that underlie the parties separate negotiating positions and how to give the parties greater confidence in the benefits of the code.

I believe one of the stumbling blocks has been a failure on the part of developed countries properly to appreciate the benefits to their economies from the code in the short term but, particularly, the longer term. The code has principally been seen in response to the demands of less developed countries. In my opinion, major and significant benefits exist for developed countries. It is particularly in this area that Australia can bring its influence to bear. There has been a desire on the part of the developed countries that developing countries undertake to observe rules of applicable international laws, specifically in relation to compensation in the event of nationalisation of concessions and the like. By the code, it will be agreed that measures taken by states should be consistent with their international obligations.

Furthermore, in protection of industrial property rights, developed countries have sought to ensure that developing countries accede to and abide by the provisions of the Paris Convention. It is now agreed that each country should ensure the effective protection of the industrial property rights granted under its national law. Somewhat flexible, it must be conceded, that at least it is a recognition of entitlement to protection which additionally-and I quote from the draft 'should be applied fairly, equitably and on the same basis to all parties in accordance with established procedures of law and principles and objectives of the Code'. The recognition of arbitration as a means of settling disputes as a worthwhile step in itself, as are the various criteria to be observed by the legislative, judicial and administrative processes of all countries. Additionally, as I said at the outset, there is a growing recognition among developed countries that, for their future trading advantage, development of the Third World will be necessary. Thus, to facilitate such development will provide returns beyond that directly related to the particular technology transaction involved.

I am suggesting from the foregoing that a universal code would be of greater value to less developed countries than national or regional schemes which may not encourage transfer. Similarly, it appears that such a code can offer considerable advantage to developed countries in contributing to a stable investment environment geared to the protection of technology suppliers property rights and removal of the risk of expropriation or infringement.

This leads me to the role Australia can play in helping the parties reach agreement. It should be possible to develop rules of reason designed to accommodate the interests of both suppliers and recipients of technology. To facilitate increased transfer, developing countries must be prepared to ensure order and predictability. To maximise the potential benefit of the transfer the developed countries must be prepared to accept that transfers should be on fair and reasonable terms and, therefore, for example, not including unreasonable restraints of trade which their unequal bargaining position might otherwise allow. Each has legitimate interests requiring the respect of the other. Australia can stress those interests.

It seems to me that developed countries have placed insufficient emphasis upon the potential advantages of the code and have thus accepted in the draft national obligations of recipient parties which, although giving encouragement of a changing attitude, are insufficient to give confidence that the terms of technology transfer contracts will be respected. It appears that such concessions have been made because of a preoccupation by developed countries to win the argument for a non-legally binding code.

Accepting the practical difficulties, the arguments for a legally enforceable code are substantial. It should be possible for the international community to reach agreements that are binding or, in other words, to reach a consensus in which no party will feel substantial loss in a legal acceptance. It has commonly occurred in relation to intra-anti-trust legislation and, with a positive attitude towards the benefits, could have occurred internationally. The outstanding disputes should not be irreconcilable. Less developed countries, in recognising the value of a truly international code, should accept the difficulties to developed countries of the group of 77 proposal in relation to jurisdiction and applicable law. In the spirit of seeking to achieve a new international attitude, developing countries must accept the desirability of denationalising such issues. Similarly, less developed countries should acknowledge the experience of the developing world that restraint of trade can, in some circumstances, be reasonable and beneficial to the community as a whole. Such determination should most fairly be made by an international tribunal.

With different attitudes and a different approach, the result could have been a legally binding fair code with benefits to all, and that should remain the ultimate long term objective of all states. But that simply will not come to pass in the short term. Is it, therefore, worth pursuing a voluntary code? I would argue that it is. Practice might prove that a voluntary code is effective and that contracting parties accept the guidelines with regard to undesirable restrictive practices and the obligations which should be accepted with transfer of technology contracts. Practice might show that less developed countries, acknowledging a change resulting from voluntary adherence to the code, more readily accept the arguments of developed countries for reasonable protection of industrial property and a right to a fair return for the research and development which has resulted in the improved technology. Therefore, I urge that Australia support the concept of a five-year voluntary code and give the international community the opportunity to put into practice, in this limited field, the spirit of the new international economic order.

In conclusion, I recognise that the code will provide but one step in overcoming the North-South dichotomy and that other proposals, such as national or regional centres for transfer of technology, regulation of transnational corporations, steps to reverse the 'brain drain' and further reform of the Paris Convention also deserve attention. But it has been fairly said that the international order which has emerged in the post-war era has been unable to satisfy the most basic aspirations of the majority of the world's peoples and, in that context, each small step which can make a positive contribution is worth while.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the present Government continuing to fund the synroc pilot plant project for storing radioactive waste; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is funding the construction of a non-radioactive pilot demonstration plant at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's Research Establishment at Lucas Heights, to manufacture full-sized canisters of synroc. The Government is also funding associated projects under the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration program in order to develop the production technology for synroc and test its performance as a medium for immobilizing radioactive materials.

Development of Synroc is a contribution by Australia to the international community, of an environmental protection technology for the resolution of radioactive waste storage and disposal problems and is consistent with the Labor Party's concern to overcome those problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1983 (Hansard, page 132), Senator Hearn asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What hormones and other additives are permitted in the diet of livestock produced for human consumption in Australia.
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In Australia, no hormones have been approved for inclusion in the diet of livestock intended for human consumption. However, a wide range of other feed additives is permitted. These are used mainly in the production of pigs and poultry, other animals being mostly range fed.

Details of these feed additives will be found in the booklet 'Livestock Feed Additives-Their Recommended Acceptable Use Levels, Claims and Limitations' which is prepared by my Department. A copy is provided for the honourable senator's information.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: United States of America: Deployment of Missiles

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1983 (Hansard, page 731), Senator Chipp asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs a question about the impending insanity of the United States of America in deploying 464 ground launched Cruise missiles and 108 Pershing missiles in Europe, which is scheduled to begin in December of this year. Is the Government aware that because of the missiles' five to eight minute flight time to Soviet territory from Europe and because of their mobility, small size and accuracy, their deployment and the potential deployment of counter-missiles by the Soviets could result in a policy of launch on warning by the Soviets? Is the Minister aware that a policy of launch on warning means that the full might of a nuclear arsenal would be released on the planet on the basis of an automatic computer alert without any reference to political or military commanders? Does the Government not believe that such a policy, given a number of reported incidents where a computer error has led to a false alert of nuclear attack causing the launching of nuclear armed aircraft, would place nuclear arsenals a hair-trigger away from being used? Will the Government use every method it has at its disposal to prevent the deployment of these missiles?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government is aware that on current plans The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation intends to deploy 572 Pershing II and Cruise missiles over the four year period December 1983 to December 1987. In the initial phase of the deployments 16 Cruise missiles will be deployed in the United Kingdom and 9 Pershing II missiles in the Federal Republic of Germany in December of this year , and 16 Cruise missiles will be deployed in Sicily commencing in February 1984. These developments result from a collective decision taken by the 16 Western governments that constitute the NATO alliance.

The planned deployments are the result of NATO's 'dual-track' decision of December 1979 whereby NATO decided to modernise its intermediate-range nuclear forces in Europe to counter the growing threat posed by the Soviet SS20 missile, while at the same time inviting the Soviet Union to engage in negotiations to limit intermediate-range nuclear missiles on both sides. The Intermediate-Range Nuclear Force-INF-negotiations opened in Geneva in November 1981.

Ground launched Cruise missiles-GLCMs-will require some time, possibly several hours, to reach their targets from scheduled deployment sites in Western Europe. I understand that the flight time for the Pershing II missiles, which will be deployed solely within the Federal Republic of Germany, will be of the order of fourteen minutes depending on the distance from the launch site to the intended target.

The warning time for these missiles could be less. These short flight and warning times would not constitute a radical break from the past. Similar considerations apply in the case of Soviet SS20 missiles already stationed in the western Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and targeted on Western Europe, and to submarine-launched ballistic missiles-SLBMs-held by both sides for some years now and stationed within range of Europe and the United States.

The Soviet Union has claimed the right to take appropriate counter measures should the NATO INF deployments proceed, but we are not aware that it has adopted or is about to adopt a policy of 'Launch-on-warning', that is, a policy which would permit a retaliatory strike to be launched when an aggressor's missiles were first detected in flight. Soviet policy on the central questions of nuclear doctrine is not entirely clear, although in its public statements at least the Soviet Union has given an undertaking that it will not be the first to use nuclear weapons. As with the United States, there is reason to believe that control over nuclear weapons in the Soviet Union is exercised at the highest political level.

The Government shares the widely expressed concerns about the possibility of the accidental outbreak of nuclear war and about reports of false alerts of nuclear attack. It would be gravely concerned about any development which increased the likelihood of nuclear war. At the same time the Government recognises that the arms control negotiations between the two super powers have increased knowledge and understanding about each side's capabilities and intentions. This process may, in turn, have helped to make it less likely that there will be an outbreak of nuclear war by accident. The Government believes that the hot-line agreements between the Soviet Union and the Western nuclear powers, as well as the 1976 Agreement on Measures to Reduce the Risk of the Outbreak of Nuclear War between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics have contributed to this process. The Government has also noted that both super powers have proposed additional confidence-building measures further designed to assist in lessening the risk of nuclear war in their current bilateral arms control negotiations in Geneva. The Australian Government welcomes this development as a practical contribution to lessening the risk of the accidental outbreak of nuclear war.

The Government is concerned that continued escalation of the arms race would increase the risk of nuclear war. For this reason it is encouraging negotiations between the super powers designed to reduce their nuclear and conventional forces. The Government would clearly prefer that a situation existed in Europe such that NATO did not consider it necessary to deploy cruise or Pershing II missiles to enhance its security. The present situation has arisen, however, because the Soviet Union was perceived by NATO to have gained an advantage through the deployment of its SS20 missiles. These deployments commenced in 1977 and the Soviet Union now has 351 SS20s in place, 243 of them assigned to Western European targets. By contrast, NATO has no comparable INF systems in place and believes the present imbalance to be detrimental to its security.

It is important that the INF negotiations should arrive at a satisfactory outcome which would be mutually agreed and verified. The zero option proposed by the United States and endorsed by NATO would have eliminated the entire range of intermediate-range nuclear missiles.
This proposal did not find favour with the Soviet Union. Australia supports the objective of imposing limits on and ultimately eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles on a global basis.

The Government urges the super powers to reach agreements which will lead to both qualitative restraints and qualitative reductions in nuclear and conventional forces. It has presented its views to the United States at the highest levels as well as to other Governments and in international discussions.
